Buyer name: Centre for Environment, Fisheries and Aquaculture Science
Title: CEFAS25-121 Request for Quotation for Hyperspectral Sensor (VNIR 400–1000 nm)
Description: The continuous and escalating pressures from climate change, biodiversity loss, pollution, and the intensified utilisation of natural habitats are placing marine ecosystems under unprecedented strain. This ongoing degradation compromises the resilience of these systems, making them more vulnerable to acute shocks like marine heat waves and spills, as well as chronic stresses such as wind farm construction. The decline in ecosystem health not only threatens fisheries and other livelihoods but also hampers our capacity for carbon absorption. To effectively manage and mitigate these challenges, there is an ever-increasing demand for cost-effective and targeted environmental monitoring. Modern technologies, including drones, computer vision, and artificial intelligence (AI), are proving invaluable in enhancing monitoring capabilities while reducing the need for intensive human involvement.However, traditional visible light surveys of benthic and coastal habitats offer limited insights into the identification of flora, fauna, and pollution. In response to these limitations, there is a growing adoption of hyperspectral imagery. This technology captures significant amounts of data beyond the visible light revealing new environmental detail, surpassing the capabilities of visible light or human monitoring.Cefas requires a sensor to develop and extend its monitoring capability for coastal and benthic environments. Hyperspectral imaging is required to detect and characterise flora and fauna on land (seaweed on rocks, on beach), sea surface (plankton, algae) and underwater (benthic epifauna and flora). In addition, ideally the sensor would allow us to detect pollutants such as plastics that are characterized more in the Short-Wave Infrared (SWIR) range of spectrum. The sensor will support near‑term pilot pipelines for: (a) benthic habitat surveys (via Cefas custom built housing) and (b) aerial shoreline surveys for plastic detection, while providing a flexible platform for future applications.Scope of Requirements:Technical RequirementThe Supplier will provide a complete hyperspectral infrared imaging solution suitable for both Remotely Piloted Aircraft (RPA) operation and laboratory use, including all necessary hardware, lenses, software and accessories required to acquire, calibrate, process and export orthorectified hyperspectral data cubes.At a minimum, the proposed system will be capable of capturing data across the Very Near Infrared (VNIR) spectral range (400–1000 nm). Ideally, a drone-mountable solution would extend coverage to include VNIR, Near Infrared (NIR), and as much of the SWIR range as feasible—targeting a full spectral span of approximately 400–2700 nm.Cefas understand that drone-compatible SWIR sensors may exceed the maximum available budget (£130,000 inc. VAT). Therefore, a hybrid approach of a drone-mounted VNIR sensor, complemented by a laboratory-based (non-flyable) SWIR system is an acceptable solution. Cefas is open to alternative configurations if the Supplier can propose a more suitable option that meets the technical requirements and stays within budget.In addition, the Supplier will provide comprehensive training on implementing data processing pipelines for hyperspectral data collected from the sensor, as well as operational support for Cefas drone pilots. This support will include training sessions covering environmental conditions, target selection, and sensor configuration to ensure optimal data collection Clear documentation of all data collection and processing steps are essential.

Title: Primary Care healthcare waste collection and disposal service to General Practice and Community Pharmacy for Bristol, North Somerset and South Gloucestershire (BNSSG) Integrated Care Board (ICB)
Description: Bristol, North Somerset and South Gloucestershire (BNSSG) Integrated Care Board (ICB) is seeking a provider with the capability and capacity to deliver a Primary Care healthcare waste collection and disposal service to General Practice and Community Pharmacy.  The services in the tender include:• Collection & transport of healthcare waste and pharmaceutical waste• Storage of healthcare waste and pharmaceutical waste• Treatment of healthcare waste and pharmaceutical waste• Incineration of healthcare waste and pharmaceutical waste• Provision of reusable and single use containers for healthcare waste and pharmaceutical• Decontamination of reusable containers for healthcare waste and pharmaceutical• Promoting waste segregation and compliance• Healthcare and pharmaceutical waste tracking data including Duty of Care complianceThe commissioner has a maximum financial envelope available of £1,480,000 per annum, inclusive of VAT.  The total maximum contract value for the 5 year Contract is £7,400,000 (inclusive VAT).  At the end of the initial contract term the Commissioner will have extension options of up to 4 years in total, made of 2 x 24 month periods, which will be awarded at the Commissioner's discretion, giving a maximum possible contract value of £13,320,000 inclusive of VAT over  9 years if the full contract term is fulfilled.The Commissioner is of the view that TUPE may apply to this serviceThe new contract will commence on the 1st of October 2026, with mobilisation planned from April 2026.This procurement is being carried out by NHS South, Central and West Commissioning Support Unit (SCW) on behalf of BNSSG ICB.

Title: Book Parcels and Maths Games for children in care
Description: The Service is to provide as a minimum six (6) parcels. These must be sent calendar monthly to the Virtual Schools nominated address, as identified for each eligible child. High-quality books from a range of genres, maths games and other high-quality materials, that are age appropriate to support our children's learning, which will support narrowing the gap in education achievements for our children.  We expect the Provider to demonstrate how and why materials included in a parcel are chosen. The Council support academic five hundred and thirty (530) children per year. The provider will be able to support additional children should the Council need to add new to care children to the Service each month. For those new to care children, we expect them to receive all parcels from the year.Supply of Materials-Staffordshire County Council invites Tenders for the provision of a Service to deliver "Educational Books and Maths Games Parcels" to eligible children in care as identified by the Staffordshire virtual school. These parcels must engage the children and young people of in reading and playing educational games through the content they provide. The Provider will supply these children with colourful parcels containing books for them to keep, maths games, stationery and other high-quality materials on a calendar monthly basis, for six (6) agreed months of the year, at an agreed start date per agreed cohort.  There will be an additional bonus parcel at Christmas. Suppliers will not be expected to provide the bonus parcel for 2025 but will be expected for the years thereafter. This brings the Total to seven (7) parcels per academic cohort.The provider will need to have available parcels that are  split by school year groups:•Children aged 4-5 in the Early Years Foundation Stage/Reception •Children in Year 1, (age 5-6) •Children in Year 2, (ages 6-7) •Children in Year 3, (ages 7-8) •Children in Year 4 (ages 8-9) •Children in Year 5, (ages 9-10) •Children in Year 6 (ages 10-11) •Children in Year 7 (ages 11-12) Note: If there is a child who is working at a lower or higher level, an appropriate parcel despite their school year group can be chosen.   The parcel packaging will be robust to contain and transport the contents by the selected postal service be  child friendly and it should not distinguish the cohort it's intended for. The packaging must however have distinguished identification (what this is will be decided between the Provider and the Council)  to allow teachers and carers to identify the package.The Virtual School will provide the current posting list each month to the provider upon request.To access the tender documents and/or place a bid for the contract please visit: https://supplierlive.proactisp2p.com/Account/Login

Title: A Health Economic Evaluation Framework And Bespoke Analysis For AMR Diagnostic Technologies
Description: PACE (Pathways to Antimicrobial Clinical Efficacy) is a £30 million initiative supporting and funding early-stage innovation in medicines and diagnostics, aimed at tackling AMR. It was established in September 2023 and is a collaboration between Innovate UK (IUK), LifeArc, and Medicines Discovery Catapult (MDC) - three leaders in the UK's health innovation and research community.The PACE programme is looking for an external provider to deliver an 'Enabling Project' in partnership related to early health economic analysis to support our cohort of AMR diagnostic innovation developers from our 2nd PACE funding call. Please see (https://paceamr.org.uk/news/ukhsa-announced-as-first-pace-collaboration-to-help-tackle-deadly-antimicrobial-resistance/) for details of our first enabling project partnering with UKHSA to provide access to clinical isolates for our first cohort of therapeutics developers.The overall purpose of this second enabling project is to provide PACE awardees and the wider AMR community with access to practical early-stage health economic outputs, including care pathway insights, indicative cost analyses, early-stage economic modelling and value proposition frameworks tailored to our cohorts emerging diagnostic technologies. These outputs will be designed to support product development decisions, stakeholder engagements and future reimbursement planning with relevance across bloodstream infections (BSI), respiratory tract infections (RTI) and urinary tract infections (UTI).To maximise impact, the provider is expected to group diagnostics with similar clinical positioning or use cases together to make the most of synergies across the cohort (e.g. when establishing the existing care pathway of the indications). Where relevant, the provider is also expected to align with existing or ongoing initiatives. A key priority is to ensure that insights, and findings from the project are made publicly available through open-access tools, share reports etc. to ensure that it benefits the broader AMR innovation community to inform future policy, funding and procurement decisions.The support required is across three work packages:Kick-off webinar: Introduce PACE awardees (diagnostics projects) to early-stage health economic assessment including its purpose, relevance and application across the cohort.Baseline development and modelling tool: Deliver care-pathway analyses (BSI, RTI and UTI) and a re-usable (modelling with guidance -enabling scenario testing using default assumptions.Project-specific deployment: Collaborate with each PACE project to input diagnostic specific data, generate tailored analyses, and refine the tool using real-world examples.

Title: WCC Housing Needs Integrated Singles and Outreach Services
Description: WCC Housing Needs Integrated Singles and Outreach ServicesThe Authority is procuring Integrated Singles and Outreach Services in three (3) Lots. The Services are a pivotal and strategically aligned provision at the heart of the Council’s Homelessness and Rough Sleeping Strategy 2024. These Services are a cornerstone of our ambition to prevent homelessness, enhance recovery, and transform lives through a dynamic, tailored, and outcomes-driven approach. The Integrated Singles and Outreach Services will be procured in three (3) Lots:Lot 1 Assertive Outreach Services: To build strong, ongoing relationships and offer consistent support to people who face long-term homelessness and multiple challenges. The Provider will provide support for complex cases, engagement strategies, and long-term recovery planning. Lot 2 First Contact Team: The Provider will act as the first point of contact for the dynamic movement of individuals into and out of rough sleeping (FLOW) and those at risk of rough sleeping. The Provider will deliver rapid and trauma informed support and early interventions to prevent and move Service Users away from Rough Sleeping at the earliest opportunity. Lot 3 Hub Support Team: the Provider will deliver a central coordination point for statutory services and housing, providing a single front door for all accommodation options. The Provider will triage Service User needs and co-ordinate support and multi-agency planning. The Provider will actively collaborate with the Authority’s services through a hybrid delivery model, helping to coordinate joined-up planning and support. The Provider will need to provide a building with working space for 20 Council staff and those commissioned to provide support functions for this Lot, as well as having the capacity for Service Users walk-in’s and confidential meetingsThe estimated Contract Commencement Date of this contract 06/02/2026. The estimated Service Commencement Date is 01/04/2026. The Initial Contract Period is 3 years, with provision for extension, at WCC’s discretion, for up to a further 4 years, providing a total contract period of up to 7 years (calculated from the Service Commencement Date), expiring no later than 31 March 2033.During the Contract Period the Authority may, at its sole discretion, require additional Services to be delivered by the Provider for up 25% of the total contract value for each Lot. This will be subject to service needs, funding and will be at the Authorities discretion in line with clause 47 of the Contract. There will be a tender event held via Microsoft Teams on Monday 18th November 2025 This is an excellent opportunity to gain insights into the tender requirements, ask questions and provide feedback.

Title: RFT for the Provision of Mechanical Services Framework at SmartPly Europe DAC ‘25
Description: Smartply Europe DAC are seeking tender submissions from suitably qualified engineering companies with extensive experience in the OSB / wood processing industry for appointment to a Framework Agreement for a range of small to medium sized Mechanical works at their plant in Bellview, Slieverue, Waterford, X91 PX75. Types of works: 1) Annual Large-scale shutdown works 2) Fortnightly shutdown works 3) Hourly rate works related to projects An example of the type of work involved is listed but not limited to the table below. The scope is designed to be comprehensive to cover potential future needs. For individual tasks, suppliers are only expected to perform the parts relevant to them. No. Maintenance Activity Performance Characteristics 1. Routine Maintenance General basic maintenance services to mechanical plant + equipment Activities that are conducted while equipment and systems are in service these are predictable and can be scheduled. Generally, these are the activities scheduled on a time-based schedule derived from preventive or predictive maintenance strategies. Some examples are visual inspections, cleaning, functional tests, and measurement of operating quantities, lubrication and oil tests. 2. Maintenance Testing Activities that involve using test equipment to assess condition in an offline state. These activities are predictable and can be scheduled and budgeted. They may be scheduled on a time or meter basis but may be planned to coincide with scheduled equipment outages. Since these activities are predictable. Some examples are governor alignments and balanced and unbalanced gate. 3. Downday Schedule Activities that involve assessing the condition of equipment after unusual events, such as equipment failure/ repair/replacement or when equipment deterioration is suspected. Therefore replacement, remedial works or modifications may need to be conducted in order to ensure the equipment is operational after the schedule downtime period has lapsed.

Title: Archives Catalogue Procurement
Description: Cambridgeshire Archives Service (CAS) holds a wealth of unique historic records and other resources relating to Cambridgeshire, the former counties of Huntingdonshire and the Isle of Ely and their communities. In order to fulfil our duties as a Place of Deposit for Public Records under the Public Records Acts and as a National Archives-accredited archive service, Cambridgeshire Archives Service requires a multi-level, ISAD(G)-compliant catalogue system to hold data about our archive documents.  The system must be securely cloud-hosted. In particular, CAS requires such a system to•provide a multi-level catalogue of all the documents and collections that CAS has already catalogued (c.500,000 entries) and the option to easily create and edit new catalogues in future•contain the six mandatory elements specified by ISAD(G) for item-level catalogue descriptions with other non-mandatory ISAD(G) elements available as optional extras or as customisable fields•link the item-level catalogue descriptions with existing barcoded locations (c.50,000 locations)•link the catalogue descriptions (at any level) with relevant accessions descriptions•link the accession catalogue descriptions with relevant document owner/donor/depositor descriptions•link the item-level catalogue descriptions with relevant digitised image file descriptions and if possible include a thumbnail of any relevant images•link the item-level catalogue descriptions with relevant conservation descriptions•have an online, publicly accessible, searchable, non-editable view of catalogue descriptions (at any level) that have been approved for public view•enable users of this public interface to easily search and find the catalogue descriptions they need •possibly enable staff to add to the public interface research guides, PDFs, online exhibitions etc (a desirable)•enable user account management and access control for staff and volunteers•and generate reports on system contents and activities.Keywords:Archiving, Software, ISAD, Catalogue

Title: SDH North Chimneys & Flues Adaptation Works
Description: Background to the requirement:The purpose of this procurement exercise is to appoint a main contractor for works to the hospital’s chimneys funded by NHS Estates Safety Funding 2025/26.  The chimneys in question, constructed around 1988, are approximately 38 meters tall from main plant room level and made of mild steel.  Externally they are located within an internal courtyard of the hospital (no vehicular access) which is approx. 7.5m above the main plant room level.Customer Objective / Scope & Specifics:Following an appraisal and optioneering studies carried out by engineering consultants Mott MacDonald, the Authority is seeking to dismantle one of the steel chimney stacks and to carry out works as described as follows:  • Install temporary boiler and generator• Switch off all main plant• Redirection of the generator flues• Removal of eastern Chimney (Stack 1)• Subsequent weatherproofing of chimney void to plant room roof• Reenergise main plant; CHP and Boiler 3 to remain isolated• Remove temporary boiler and generator plantThe site is located at Salisbury District Hospital, Odstock Road, Salisbury, Wiltshire, SP2 8BJ.

Title: Outdoor Fitness and Recreation Equipment Installation (Calisthenics Rig, Multi-Use Games Area Upgrade, and Rebound Wall)
Description: North Mundham Parish Council invites tenders for the design, supply, and installation of outdoor recreational equipment at North Mundham Playing Field, School Lanen North Mundham, Chichester, West Sussex, PO20 1LA. The project includes:•A calisthenics rig under 4 metres high•An upgrade to the existing Multi-Use Games Area (MUGA)•Installation of a rebound wall with graphics2. Project ScopeA. Calisthenics RigThe rig must:•Be no higher than 4 metres•Be installed on grass matting that meets safety and durability standards•Be constructed from galvanised steel•Include the following features:oMonkey barsoHoop (e.g., gymnastic ring or circular climbing element)oActivity generator (multi-functional element to encourage varied movement)•Be designed with a female-friendly specification, including:oErgonomic grip sizesoAccessible height optionsoInclusive design features to encourage participation across gendersB. Multi-Use Games Area (MUGA) UpgradeThe existing MUGA space measures 8.95m x 22.95m. The upgrade must include:•Use of the existing floor space•Installation of fencing:oSide fencing height: 2 metresoEnd fencing height to incorporate:Entrance via goalBasketball hoop•Line markings for multiple sports (e.g., football, basketball, netball)•Replacement and disposal of existing goals, hoops, and fencing C. Rebound WallA rebound wall must be installed adjacent to the existing tennis court. It must include:•Durable construction suitable for outdoor use•Graphics featuring:oA targetoCricket stumps•Design that encourages ball games and skill development3. Contractor Responsibilities•Site preparation and groundworks•Supply and installation of all equipment and materials•Compliance with all relevant safety standards (e.g., BS EN 1176/1177)•Post-installation inspection and certification•Provision of maintenance and warranty documentation4. Tender Submission RequirementsSubmissions must include:•Detailed design proposals and technical specifications•Visuals or concept drawings•Installation timeline and project milestones•Total cost breakdown (separately identifying VAT where applicable)•Evidence of relevant experience and qualifications•Health & safety compliance documentation•Warranty and aftercare details•Evidence of waste disposal licence 5. Evaluation CriteriaTenders will be evaluated based on:•Compliance with specifications•Quality and durability of materials•Safety and inclusivity features•Cost-effectiveness•Proposed timeline•Supplier experience and references6. Site VisitInterested contractors are encouraged to arrange a site visit prior to submission. Please contact Louise Chater to schedule.7. Submission DeadlineAll tenders must be submitted by 11:59pm 15th December 2025 to:clerk@northmundham.org or North Mundham Parish Council, 1 Charlmead, East Wittering, Chichester, West Sussex, PO20 8DN8. Contact InformationFor further information or to arrange a site visit, please contact:Louise Chater clerk@northmundham.org 01243 203050

Title: Website Upgrade
Description: SRUC is looking to update its current external website CMS, Umbraco, to the latest version available as well as rebuild elements within it in order to take full advantage of the updated system.Key objectives for this contract include, but are not limited to:1 mitigation of cyber security risk;2 enhanced website performance;3 improved user experience and accessibility;4 improved brand consistency, uniformity, and alignment site-wide best value for money in terms of acquisition and maintenance of the upgraded website;5 a solution that supports SRUC’s net zero aspirations and Scope 3 carbon reporting.Lot 1: SRUC is looking to update its current external website CMS, Umbraco, to the latest version available as well as rebuild elements within it in order to take full advantage of the updated system.Key objectives for this contract include, but are not limited to:1 mitigation of cyber security risk;2 enhanced website performance;3 improved user experience and accessibility;4 improved brand consistency, uniformity, and alignment site-wide best value for money in terms of acquisition and maintenance of the upgraded website;5 a solution that supports SRUC’s net zero aspirations and Scope 3 carbon reporting.Each Tenderer must complete and submit along with their tender the Single Procurement Document (Scotland) (SPD). The SPD sets Minimum Standards that suppliers must achieve. Within each submitted SPD response, Tenderers should note the following selection criteria :1 It is a mandatory requirement that the tenderer holds Umbraco Gold or Platinum certification. Copies of certificates must be provided with the tender submission. Lower or alternative certification shall not be considered;2 That they hold full ISO27001 accreditation, or equivalent. Copies of certification must be provided with the tender submission;3 That their insurance cover meets the following levels:Employer’s Compulsory Liability Insurance (GBP10 million)Professional Indemnity Insurance (GBP5 million)Public Liability Insurance (GBP10 million)

Title: Book Parcels and Maths Games for Children in Care
Description: The Service is to provide as a minimum six (6) parcels. These must be sent calendar monthly to the Virtual Schools nominated address, as identified for each eligible child. High-quality books from a range of genres, maths games and other high-quality materials, that are age appropriate to support our children's learning, which will support narrowing the gap in education achievements for our children.  We expect the Provider to demonstrate how and why materials included in a parcel are chosen. The Council support academic five hundred and thirty (530) children per year. The provider will be able to support additional children should the Council need to add new to care children to the Service each month. For those new to care children, we expect them to receive all parcels from the year.Supply of Materials-Staffordshire County Council invites Tenders for the provision of a Service to deliver "Educational Books and Maths Games Parcels" to eligible children in care as identified by the Staffordshire virtual school. These parcels must engage the children and young people of in reading and playing educational games through the content they provide. The Provider will supply these children with colourful parcels containing books for them to keep, maths games, stationery and other high-quality materials on a calendar monthly basis, for six (6) agreed months of the year, at an agreed start date per agreed cohort.  There will be an additional bonus parcel at Christmas. Suppliers will not be expected to provide the bonus parcel for 2025 but will be expected for the years thereafter. This brings the Total to seven (7) parcels per academic cohort.The provider will need to have available parcels that are  split by school year groups:•Children aged 4-5 in the Early Years Foundation Stage/Reception •Children in Year 1, (age 5-6) •Children in Year 2, (ages 6-7) •Children in Year 3, (ages 7-8) •Children in Year 4 (ages 8-9) •Children in Year 5, (ages 9-10) •Children in Year 6 (ages 10-11) •Children in Year 7 (ages 11-12) Note: If there is a child who is working at a lower or higher level, an appropriate parcel despite their school year group can be chosen.   The parcel packaging will be robust to contain and transport the contents by the selected postal service be  child friendly and it should not distinguish the cohort it's intended for. The packaging must however have distinguished identification (what this is will be decided between the Provider and the Council)  to allow teachers and carers to identify the package.The Virtual School will provide the current posting list each month to the provider upon request.To access the tender documents and/or place a bid for the contract please visit: https://supplierlive.proactisp2p.com/Account/Login

Title: Tender for the provision of Postal Delivery of Nicotine Replacement Therapy in Herefordshire

The Herefordshire Healthy Lifestyle Service provides the Herefordshire Stop Smoking Service (HSSS) and is commissioned by Public Health to provide the recommended standard treatment programme and supply of NRT to their clients to support a stop smoking quit attempt.The objectives of the service are to support individuals who want to stop smoking, and to reach individuals in rural areas of Herefordshire who do not have access to a community Pharmacy in their local area and have limited means of directly accessing NRT.The contract will commence upon 1 January 2026 and will continue until 31 December 2027. There will be an option to extend this contract for up to 24 months (extensions are subject to future funding and budget approvals, internal governance and supplier's satisfactory performance).

Title: Outsourced Provision of Multiple Clinical Services NLAG
Description: NHS Humber Health Partnership intends to follow the most suitable provider process for the provision of Multiple Clinical Services for patients in the North and North East Lincolnshire area.  The intention is to publish this notice so providers who can deliver all of these services are able to express their interest. <br/><br/>Proposed length of contract and estimated value<br/>The intention is to award a contract from 15/12/2026 to 31/03/2026 with options to extend for 3 months.<br/><br/>Based on current activity levels and requirements the maximum estimated contract value is approximately £225,000<br/><br/>Service requirements<br/>The Provider must provide the following clinical services:<br/>Orthopaedic surgery<br/>Urology procedures<br/><br/>The provider must <br/>Have a minimum of 2 theatres<br/>Be able to mobilise the services and provide capacity within 2 weeks of confirmation of award<br/>Be able a local provider to minimise transport for patients for mobility and financial reasons.<br/>Have access to diagnostics (including x-ray, CT and MRI)<br/>Employ Staff locally with opportunities for apprenticeship<br/>Be CQC registered<br/>Provide plans to be carbon neutral by 2040<br/>Provide modern slavery policies<br/><br/>Only providers who are able to provide all the appropriately qualified, experienced and skilled staff will be considered. This is a key requirement. All staff must have the suitable skills, qualifications and competencies to undertake the specified work.  All staff who work under the provider must possess the appropriate qualification/certification, Enhanced Disclosure and Barring Service (DBS) check and possess prior NHS experience. All patients need to be treated in line with accepted national standards and NICE guidance. <br/><br/>CPV Codes <br/>85111101-1 Surgical hospital services<br/>85121280-9Ophthalmologist, dermatology or orthopaedics services<br/>85121292-6Urologist services<br/><br/>Full specification/requirements are available in the documents that can be accessed in the Atamis e-procurement portal.Lot 1: This notice is an intention to award a contract under the Health Care Services (Provider Selection Regime) Regulations 2023 Most Suitable Provider process.<br/><br/>Procurement of outsourced multiple clinical services in the local community.<br/><br/>CPV Code: 8500000-0 Health Services<br/>Full services specifications available via the Atamis e-procurement portal.<br/><br/>The contract will be for an initial term 15/12/2025 to 31/03/2026 with option to extend for 3 months.<br/><br/>Estimated contract value is £225,000.<br/><br/>The deadline for the submission of compliant expressions of interest is 17:00hrs on Wednesday 26th November 2025.

Title: North Paddington Global Majority Mental Health Pilot
Description: Westminster City Council (WCC) is commissioning a pilot service to deliver culturally appropriate, community-led mental health support for Global Majority (GM) residents in the North Paddington wards of Queen's Park, Harrow Road, and Westbourne. This 18-month pilot, with a total pre-tendered budget of £280,000, aims to provide early-intervention psychological support, outreach and engagement activities, and workforce development through a train-the-trainer programme for local VCS organisations.Lot 1: Westminster City Council (WCC) is commissioning a pilot service to deliver culturally appropriate, community-led mental health support for Global Majority (GM) residents in the North Paddington wards of Queen's Park, Harrow Road, and Westbourne. Title: Understanding the Heritage Dividend UID 112/NP 389
Description: This project aims to improve our understanding of when and why heritage investment triggers a ‘heritage dividend’—a catalytic effect where initial heritage-led projects stimulate significant follow-on investment and sustained regeneration. Building on nine High Street Heritage Action Zone case studies and exemplar projects like Nottingham's Lace Market and the North Kent coastal town of Whitstable, the research will develop a theory of change explaining the mechanisms (such as confidence signalling, clustering, identity reinforcement and cultural branding) and enabling conditions that produce durable impacts. Deliverables include a theory of change model, reports, policy brief, stakeholder workshop, and comparative data. For more detailed information please see the attached ITT.

Title: SCE0045 Dementia Support Service Soft Market Test
Description: THIS IS NOT A CALL FOR COMPETITIONDementia Support ServicesIntroductionLeicester City Council and Leicestershire County Council are considering commissioning a Dementia Support Service. It is anticipated, dependent upon an engagement exercise, that tenders for this service would be sought in 03/04 2026, to enable a new contract to begin from 01/ 10/ 2026.As part of the commissioning process, the authority is undertaking a soft market test. This gives potential providers and other stakeholders the opportunity to express their interests and feed in their views about the potential service model and specification principles. The commissioners will use the information to appraise options and further develop the specification.This process does not constitute a formal tender or other competitive bidding process and will not result in the letting of a Contract. The authority is using this process solely to test the market to gather information and ascertain the level of interest in this particular service. There are therefore no formal criteria which we will use to judge your responses, and it is not our intention to provide any feedback.Keywords:Dementia, health, care

Title: Carbon Calculator, Verification and Labelling System
Description: Coimisiún na Meán requires a Carbon Calculator, Verification and Labelling system for the purpose of accurately tracking and routinely reporting on the environmental sustainability performance of TV and film production in Ireland based on national and international emission factors. The purpose of this service will ensure the delivery of environmental sustainability recommendations documented in the Future of Media Commission Implementation Strategy and Action Plan. The Media Development team will use the service to provide the Irish media sector and associated stakeholders with accurate and actionable data on the source of carbon emissions within their production. The envisaged duration of the contract is 2 (two) YEARS with an option to extend by 1 (one) YEAR.

Title: Single Building Assessment - Approved Assessor and Verifier
Description: Renfrewshire Council has the requirement to appoint a Scottish Government Approved consultant to undertake up to 14 Single Building Assessments (SBA's) in accordance with the procedures set out in the Scottish Government Technical Guidance.Lot 1: Renfrewshire Council has the requirement to appoint an approved Scottish Government Single Building Assessment Consultant to carry out Single Building Assessments to 14 High Rises across Renfrewshire. These assessments are required to be carried out as part of the Cladding Remediation Programme that is administered by the Scottish Government. The Consultant appointed will carry out an initial gateway assessment to determine if a full single building assessment is required. If a full Single Building Assessment is required, they will carry this out and then the work will be verified by a different consultant from the appointed organisation. The Assessment and Verification process must be carried out in line with the Cladding Remediation Programme: Single Building Assessment Specification. Tenderers will provide a fixed price for the following: Initial Gateway Assessment Full Single Building Assessment Peer Review of Single Building Assessment Tenderers bidding for this Contract must be Scottish Government Approved Single Building Assessment Consultants.. Tenderers must be Scottish Government Authorised Single Building Assessment (SBA) Providers to bid for this Contract.

Title: HC2278 Wiltshire Council Health Eating Programme For Schools
Description: Wiltshire Council Health Eating programme for schools Market Engagement Event InvitationWiltshire Council is hosting a market engagement event ahead of procuring a contract for the delivery of a whole-setting approach to healthy eating support programme for schools.Scope of ServiceThe proposed scheme includes:•A school-setting provision to support pupils aged 2-11 and their families with healthy eating and improving their understanding of a healthy lifestyle. The provision should influence change and improvements in all aspects of school-life, including after-school family support, embedding healthy lifestyle education into the learning environment, the food environments, policies related to food and healthy lifestyle. The provision must include a sustainability/legacy aspect to ensure schools continue to embed the key values and objectives of the provision, and, where applicable, if required provide ad-hoc support to re-establish those values and objectives. The project must align with the Wiltshire's Healthy School Award accreditation requirements for Healthy Weight and Whole School Approach so that the support can be used as evidence for accreditation. This includes early-years settings and SEND schools.Anticipated start dateThe contract will be anticipated to start on 1st September 2026. Contract length of 2 years + 2 (extension option).Estimated Total Contract Value•£210,000 inc. VAT Market Engagement Event DetailsThis online engagement session will provide an overview of the project, procurement route, and key requirements for interested suppliers:•Date: Thursday 27th November 2025•Time: 10:00am – 11:00am•Location: Microsoft Teams (link provided upon registration)To register your interest and receive the joining link, please contact: [email protected]Keywords:education and training services

Title: New Bicester HWRC (Household Waste Recycling Centre) consultancy support
Description: Oxfordshire County Council (OCC) operates a network of seven Household Waste and Recycling Centres (HWRCs) across the county. The northern area, particularly around Bicester, is experiencing rapid growth. Currently, this area is served only by the HWRC at Ardley Fields, which is not owned by the Council and is subject to a lease expiring in September 2026.The proposed new HWRC in Bicester is intended to replace the Ardley Fields site upon its closure.Oxfordshire County Council is seeking to appoint a consultancy to act as Principal Designer, Technical Advisor, and Project Manager. The appointed Supplier will be responsible for the design, planning, and supporting procurement of the Principal Contractor, and overall delivery of the project.The Supplier is expected to provide a multi-disciplinary design service in accordance with the OCC Consultant Scope of Services -Traditional.

Title: Provision of Counselling Supervision
Description: UK 4 Tender NoticeTitle: Counselling SupervisionTerm of Contract: Three years with the option to extend for two years in annual increments starting April 2026. Total (estimated) Contract Value: £30,000.00Procurement Act 2023 Procedure: Open ProcedureThe Service to be providedCounsellors are required to have clinical supervision, which is focused on ensuring safe and effective practice. Wrexham County Borough Council wishes to appoint Counselling Supervisors to provide the support required by counsellors and also to ensure the provision of a high-quality service to children and young people. What commissioners are asking for?The Provider will support counsellors through the supervisory process in maintaining a current awareness of best practice in open, unlimited counselling as well as time limited counselling, and in implementing this within both professional and service policies, standards and guidelines. The purpose will be to: maintain a current awareness of service policies, guidelines and standards; identify any new training or development needs required to meet presenting client problems; and to advise on quality and performance issues identified from within the supervisory process.•The Provider must be aware that, due to the demand on the service, time-limited counselling may be instigated.•The Provider will promote and support the development of reflective practice through the supervisory process with both individuals and possibly small groups.•The Provider will play an active role, in conjunction with the Health and Well Being Lead and the Advanced Practitioner for Wellbeing/ Counsellor Co-ordinator, in the identification of training and development needs as they emerge within supervision, so that professional and service development needs are met.Who the Service is forThe service will be provided for counsellors responsible for providing Counselling to children and young people.  Each Supervisory Counsellor will work with a maximum of 8 counsellors.

Title: NBI Energy Centre - Next Generation Infrastructure Programme
Description: This package of works forms part of the Next Generation Infrastructure (NGI) Programme, a funded development programme looking to develop the facilities across Norwich Research Park to transform the existing capabilities of John Innes Centre (JIC) and The Sainsbury Laboratory (TSL), both internally recognised centres of excellence in plant and microbial science. NGI will address the deterioration of infrastructure at JIC and TSL to create a world-class facility that will engage with its surroundings, is outward looking and promotes collaboration and innovation to supercharge JIC and TSL's ability to translate scientific knowledge into practical solutions.As part of the NGI Programme, JIC is looking to procure, on behalf of Norwich Bioscience Institutes (NBI), the services of a specialist contractor for the proposed design, supply, installation, financing and ongoing service provision associated with a Combined Heat and Power system (CHP Engines) within the new NBI Energy Centre located at JIC (the project).In respect of the capital cost of the CHP Engines, JIC is considering funding arrangements and will either use capital funding or seek to enter into a finance arrangement (hire purchase or lease) with the appointed contactor.  The invitation to tender documents will confirm which financing structure is being taken forward by JIC.

Title: HSHAZ Programme Evaluation – Impact Insights - UID 139
Description: In March 2025, Historic England published its evaluation of the £95 million High Street Heritage Action Zones (HSHAZ) programme. We have an opportunity to build on this work by commissioning a data journalist to examine existing data and evidence and present it in a way that is engaging and impactful for a wide public audience. This project seeks to test if, and how, data journalism might be applied to the data generated through the HSHAZ programme and its evaluation.For more detailed information please see the attached request for quote.

Buyer name: Derry City and Strabane District Council
Title: T25-179CAP Drumahoe Greenway Lighting Contractors PQQ Application
Description: Derry City and Strabane District Council seeks tenders from suitably qualified contractors for the provision of new lighting along the existing greenway paths at Drumahoe Park in Derry/Londonderry. The main part of the paths to be lite are located in the low lying greenspace adjoining the River Faughan, which is a flood plain. One path, to be lite, connects the greenspace to play area, pitch, changing rooms and car park at Drumahoe Road, via a steep wooded slope. The proposed works will also include some associated works such as site clearance, drainage, landscaping, fencing, repair of path surfacing and street furniture, etc. Your submission must be submitted via etendersNI, via this CFT. No other method of submissions will be accepted. Please refer to the CfT documents for further detail.

Title: Provision of Drainage Services

Title: Coroner's Removal Contract: Lot A
Description: The Contract is for the Coroner’s Removal Contract - Lot A: covering the administrative areas of the London Boroughs of Lambeth and Southwark for the Inner South London Coroner's Court Consortium (ISLCCC), comprising the London Boroughs of Lambeth, Lewisham and Southwark and the Royal Borough of Greenwich, with the London Borough of Southwark acting as the lead authority for the administrative areas of the ISLCC.The Supplier is to provide a coroner removals service for the transportation of bodies from the place of death to a nominated public mortuary as instructed by the Coroner.The Supplier is to provide backup services for the Coroner’s Removal Contract - Lot B: covering the administrative areas of the London Borough of Lewisham and the Royal Borough of Greenwich, which is already in place.

Title: Resurfacing
Description: Chesterfield Borough Council is seeking a Contractor to maintain its corporate property throughout the Borough. This includes Chesterfield's town centre and surface car parks.The works covered by the contract includes for repairing potholes, erecting street name plates, installation of street furniture, installation of kerbs, and resetting and repointing cobbles/Belgian setts/paving flags and any other works deemed necessary to be included in the contract.The area of work covered by the contract is situated within the Borough of Chesterfield.

Title: LDC & EBBC - Bus Shelter Provision, Advertising & Maintenance
Description: Bus shelters within the Lewes District and Eastbourne Borough Councils (LEC) portfolio provide comfort and protection from the elements to waiting passengers and a means of providing public transport information, as well as a medium for providing viable and profitable commercial advertising in high footfall and vehicle traffic areas. The Councils are seeking to engage an experienced Contractor to work with the Councils to install and maintain a portfolio of bus shelters and raise revenue from the sale of advertising from units positioned on or within the bus shelters. The primary focus of the contract is the provision of high-quality bus shelters and associated advertising revenue, with special consideration for innovation and added value through digitisation or other means such as the introduction of FSU’s.

Title: Reflect Project
Description: Tenders are invited for the Reflect Project.This is a regional project (Carmarthenshire, Pembrokeshire, Ceredigion, and Powys) which will deliver a trauma-informed, recovery-oriented social care support service for parents (primarily mothers) who have experienced the removal of one or more children through care proceedings.These individuals often face complex, interrelated challenges including poor mental health, substance misuse, domestic abuse, housing instability, and social isolation.This service aims to break that cycle through timely, person-centred, non-judgemental intervention and support. Title: Framework for The Provision of Suitable Housing for Separated Young Adults 18+
Description: Cumberland Council is looking to procure a (closed) framework for providers with the capacity, required skills and experience to deliver a service for the Provision of Suitable Housing for Separated Young Adults 18+.Separated young people are aged less than 18 years arriving in the UK unaccompanied by a parent or guardian, and who claim asylum. On entry to the UK, these young people become cared for by Cumberland Council.When a separated young person reaches the age of 18, (become a young adult), under Sections 23C-E and 24 of the Children Act, as amended by the Children Leaving Care Act 2000, Local Authorities continue to have duties and powers in respect of separated young adults.Before receiving right to remain, the young adults have no recourse to public funds and therefore cannot enter into tenancy agreements for a home. This service seeks to provide suitable accommodation for these young adults. In addition to accommodation an element of low level support will also be required to negotiate the right to remain process, and once acquired, to support the young adults to find permanent homes and access all benefit entitlements.The council proposes to enter into the framework from the 1st March 2026 with the successful tenderers. The initial framework period is from 1st March 2026 - 28th February 2029. The framework end date of 28th February 2030 is the date the framework will end if the potential 12 months extension is used. Use of this extension is at the absolute discretion of the council. Any extension will be confirmed with the successful suppliers if implemented.The highest estimated value is £1,076,400 excluding VAT. This is for the initial term and the potential 12 months extension period.The Framework is divided into three Lots:• Lot 1: Flexible BlockThe Authority guarantees a minimum number of beds with the ability to add/reduce that level (where there is a change in demand) upon notice.• Lot 2: Fixed BlockA block contract for a specified number of beds for the life of the contract.• Lot 3: Direct AwardA contract for an individual to be used in the event of an emergency, extenuating circumstances, service user choice, or in other circumstances that the Authority considers it appropriate for meeting the needs of the young adults.For further details and to access the tender documents, including the service specification, use the council's online procurement portal - The Chest - https://www.the-chest.org.uk.Registration on The Chest is free. All bids must be received electronically via The Chest by the closing date stated in the ITT.Any clarifications you have about the tender must be sent via messaging on The Chest by the closing date stated in the ITT.Keywords:Asylum Seeking, Housing Accommodation, Separated, Support Formerly Cared For, Young, Adults

Title: Provision of Website Services
Description: Orkney Islands Council has a requirement for a redisigned corporate website based on feedback received from users. Together with the new website, the Authority will require 5 years of maintenance and support for the website.Lot 1: The Authority has a requirement for a redesigned Orkney Islands Council website based on extensive user feedback. The website receives over 50 thousand users a month and has been improved over recent years (see Appendix C within OIC Website - Specification V1-1 document). However, it still has significant usability challenges, particularly with navigation, with many users resorting to Google searches instead of navigating the site directly. The new website is requested to address these issues through a user-centred design approach, focusing on simplicity, accessibility, mobile responsiveness, and a modern aesthetic -ensuring that users can find what they need in 3-4 clicks. The specification has been based around user feedback from a public survey conducted in April-May 2025 and from a diverse staff reference group who have been involved in the improvements to the website over the past few years.

Title: MBC - Invitation to Tender For the provision of Commercial Waste Services
Description: In response to the recent introduction of the Simpler Recycling 2025 legislation, Maidstone Borough Council (MBC) conducted a comprehensive review of its waste collection and disposal arrangements. This assessment underscored the necessity for appointing a qualified service provider who can support the Council’s evolving waste management strategy, particularly in enhancing recycling rates across its operational estate and reducing Scope 3 emissions associated with staff and leisure facilities. As such, MBC has been assessing the Council’s waste output on a monthly basis, generating internal and external actions to assess weights and volumes of general waste versus recycling streams. Tenderers are expected to offer this service in the form of a report, alongside general key performance indicators.It should be noted that certain locations are excluded from this contract, including parks, public litter collections, industrial units, and properties under full leasehold arrangements.The Council’s current waste management contract is due to expire in February 2026. MBC is therefore seeking to procure a long-term solution through this tender process, with the objective of ensuring a seamless transition and continuity of service, without any interruption to collections. Furthermore, MBC will be undertaking a significant refurbishment of its main office premises- Maidstone House and The Link (MBC01)- in spring 2026, which will involve a phased programme of floor closures between May- December 2026 (final dates subject to final programme by Main Contractor). It is imperative that prospective suppliers demonstrate flexibility and adaptability in service delivery throughout the contract term, as the Council reserves the right to amend the scope of services in response to operational requirements. Such amendments may include, but are not limited to, changes in:1.Frequency of waste collection services2.Number of waste containers provided3.Container sizes4.Types of waste streams collected5.Addition or removal of sites under the contractFor more information about this opportunity, please visit the Delta eSourcing portal at: https://www.delta-esourcing.com/tenders/UK-UK-Maidstone:-Transport-services-%28excl.-Waste-transport%29./96W849PD68To respond to this opportunity, please click here: https://www.delta-esourcing.com/respond/96W849PD68

Buyer Category: Agencies and non-departmental public bodies, Central healthcare organisations
Title: THE PROVISION OF REMOTE HEALTH MONITORING TECHNOLOGIES TO SUPPORT CLINICAL CARE IN THE AMBULATORY SETTING FOR THE HEALTH SERVICE EXECUTIVE
Description: The Health Service Executive (HSE) invites Expressions of Interest submission from suitably qualified service providers (referred to as “Candidates” in Stage 1 of this Restricted Procedure), to provide Remote Health Monitoring Technology solution(s) to Support Clinical Care in the Ambulatory Setting (referred to as the ‘Solution’), as described within the Specification of Services at Section 1 of this Request To Participate (RTP) (the “Services”) for the HSE. Government (Sláintecare Report), departmental (Digital for Care 2030), and organisational strategy (HSE Corporate Plan 2025-2027), respectively note the potential to expand the use of telehealth services as a key mechanism to enable care delivery closer to home, earlier discharge from secondary care services, and to enhance access to services for patients and families. Remote health monitoring has emerged as a viable clinical tool, that is a safe and efficient alternative to care provision in conventional clinical settings. Remote health monitoring technologies facilitate the provision of safe care that allows clinicians to remotely monitor the vital signs, physical symptoms, chronic conditions, and patient feedback of suitable patients thus supporting the receipt of the care, monitoring, and treatment they need from where they call home. Clinical pathways incorporating remote health monitoring enables, but is not limited to, (i) care delivered remotely by a multidisciplinary team if clinically appropriate and with clear lines of clinical responsibility and governance, (ii) chronic disease management in the community, (iii) the avoidance of hospital admission/attendance, and/or early hospital discharge, and (iv) increased service capacity and efficiency without additional physical clinical setting development. A core objective in expanding the use of remote health monitoring technologies is to assist in the provision of clinical care remotely in a coordinated and integrated way. This approach will increase the capacity of the health service to manage patient care without additional physical clinical setting development, and improve the efficiency of service delivery. This procurement process is on behalf of the Health Service Executive (HSE) including all Regional Health Areas and organisations fully or partly funded by the HSE, in addition to other publicly funded agencies. The HSE is seeking to procure an effective and market proven end-to-end, fully vendor managed solution with a Single Supplier, which is ready for immediate deployment. This solution will encompass, but is not limited to, the provision and support of a suite of web-based application(s) and clinical measurement equipment, the logistical management of platform(s) and associated devices, support for implementations, and maintenance and decontamination of associated devices. The purpose of this Expression of Interest stage in this procurement process is to pre-qualify suitable service providers, who will subsequently be invited to participate in the second Invitation to Tender stage of this procurement competition.

Title: PACE - A health economic evaluation framework and bespoke analysis for AMR Diagnostic Technologies
Description: PACE (Pathways to Antimicrobial Clinical Efficacy) is a £30 million initiative supporting and funding early-stage innovation in medicines and diagnostics, aimed at tackling AMR. It was established in September 2023 and is a collaboration between Innovate UK (IUK), LifeArc, and Medicines Discovery Catapult (MDC) – three leaders in the UK's health innovation and research community.PACE brings together the funding, resources, and partnerships to help innovators progress their early-stage antimicrobial drug and diagnostics projects with greater speed, support and confidence – giving the best AMR innovations the greatest chance of success. PACE is in the process of onboarding a cohort of projects into its portfolio from its 2024 Diagnostics Funding Round and by November expects to have onboarded between 4-6 early stage (TRL2-5) projects seeking to advance AMR diagnostics that have potential to reduce unnecessary prescribing, provide faster results to indicate which antibiotic should be used and/or catalyse the move to personalised, narrow-spectrum treatments. Projects are developing diagnostic solutions for urinary tract, lower respiratory tract and blood stream (including sepsis) infections.The PACE programme is looking for an external provider to deliver an ‘Enabling Project’ in partnership related to early health economic analysis to support our cohort of AMR diagnostic innovation developers from our 2nd PACE funding call. Please see (https://paceamr.org.uk/news/ukhsa-announced-as-first-pace-collaboration-to-help-tackle-deadly-antimicrobial-resistance/) for details of our first enabling project partnering with UKHSA to provide access to clinical isolates for our first cohort of therapeutics developers.The overall purpose of this second enabling project is to provide PACE awardees and the wider AMR community with access to practical early-stage health economic outputs, including care pathway insights, indicative cost analyses, early-stage economic modelling and value proposition frameworks tailored to our cohorts emerging diagnostic technologies. These outputs will be designed to support product development decisions, stakeholder engagements and future reimbursement planning with relevance across bloodstream infections (BSI), respiratory tract infections (RTI) and urinary tract infections.Keywords:PACE

Title: Community and Psychological Support (CAPS) for Cardiff East Cluster
Description: The NHS Wales Shared Services Partnership, hosted by Velindre NHS Trust, are acting on behalf of Cardiff and Vale University Local Health Board who are seeking to award a contract for Community and Psychological Support (CAPS) for Cardiff East Cluster. This service aims to deliver an innovative, holistic model of care that integrates social prescribing with guided psychological self-help for individuals registered with one of the four GP practices in the East Cardiff Cluster. The CAPS initiative will support vulnerable and at-risk groups experiencing mild to moderate mental health issues through an 8-session intervention pathway, combining assessment, tailored self-help strategies, and relapse prevention. The service will be delivered by two full-time practitioners based in GP practices, working collaboratively with community partners to strengthen local networks and improve mental wellbeing. The provider will also be expected to support digital referral systems, attend cluster meetings, and embed principles of person-centred care, equality, and sustainability throughout service delivery.Lot 1: The NHS Wales Shared Services Partnership, hosted by Velindre NHS Trust, are acting on behalf of Cardiff and Vale University Local Health Board who are seeking to award a contract for the delivery of Community and Psychological Support (CAPS) within the Cardiff East Cluster.This procurement is for a third sector provider to deliver a holistic, community-based support service that integrates social prescribing with guided psychological self-help.The CAPS model will consist of an eight-session intervention pathway, beginning with an initial assessment, followed by sessions focused on social prescribing, guided self-help strategies, and concluding with relapse prevention. The service will be delivered by two full-time practitioners, based within GP practices, who will work collaboratively with patients and community partners to address mild to moderate mental health needs and improve overall wellbeing.The provider will be expected to:-Deliver person-centred care aligned with the “What Matters” principle.-Utilise evidence-based tools such as those from the Centre for Clinical Interventions (CCI).-Apply Routine Outcome Measures (ROMs) and Patient Reported Experience/Outcome Measures (PREMs/PROMS).-Support the development and use of the Elemental software platform for seamless referrals.-Attend Cluster and GMS Collaborative meetings to maintain engagement with primary care professionals.-Build strong relationships with voluntary and statutory services within the Cluster.-Ensure service accessibility in both Welsh and English, and accommodate diverse communication needs including BSL and interpreter services.-Embed principles from key Welsh legislation including the Well-being of Future Generations (Wales) Act 2015, Mental Health (Wales) Measure 2010, and the Social Services and Well-being (Wales) Act 2014.The contract value is capped at 80,000GBP per annum which includes practitioner salaries and administrative support.

Title: Exported Electricity
Description: Nottingham City Council is seeking tenders from registered Electricity Suppliers in the UK to purchase the electricity export and the associated ROCs and REGO's from a Steam Turbine Embedded Generator owned and operated by Nottingham City Council.  Nottingham City Council (NCC) who own and operate a steam turbine located within the City that provides power to a private wire network and exports excess electricity to the local distribution grid. The steam is provided from the waste and energy facility at Eastcroft and the steam turbine is located at the London Rd Heat Station within the City. The generator also produces Renewable Obligation Certificates (ROC's) and Renewable Electricity Guarantees of Origin certificates (REGO Certificates).

Title: LA3541C - RFT for the Supply, Delivery, Installation, Commissioning and Calibration of a Bioreactor Suite for Bioprocess Optimisation and Digestion Fermentation Modelling for University College Dublin
Description: University College Dublin request Tenders for the supply, delivery and installation of a bioreactor platform for small-scale fermentation. The bioreactor platform must be capable of running parallel experiments in all the benchtop bioreactors with independent process control. The platform should consist of 3 x 3000 ml and 7 x 500 ml vessels. Each vessel should have the following accessories/measurements: ● Rushton impeller ● pH ● Dissolved Oxygen ● Heating - Heating Jacket ● Porous sparger ● Cooling ● Additional Gas line ● Level/foam sensor The following accessories/measurements are required on some of the systems ● Mass flow controller – Air (on 3 x 3000 ml and 3 x 500 ml), ● Advanced software (on at least 2 x 3000 ml and 2 x 500 ml) ● Biomass/OD (on 3 x 3000 ml and 3 x 500 ml) ● Off gas (on 1 x 3000 ml and 1 x 500 ml) ● Off gas integration (on 2 x 3000 ml and 2 x 500 ml) ● ORP sensor (on 2 x 3000 ml and 3 x 500 ml) ● Weight balance (on 1 x 3000 ml and 2 x 500 ml) ● Marine Impeller (on 2 x 3000 ml and 2 x 500 ml) All systems require ● Power backup in the form of UPS power supply ● Computer(s) for monitoring, logging and controlling operation ● Compressor air supply in the form of a “silent” compressor In addition the following supplementary equipment is required ● Autoclave: Vertical configuration to house vessel including the 3000 ml systems ● A shaking incubator for inoculum preparation Also the e-tender should cover the cost of Installation, Training and Carriage. Overall the bioreactor platform must enable the researchers to perform design of experiments and record process parameters reliably to facilitate technology transfer to pilot/industry scale.

Title: IT3526C TCD – RFT for the Supply and Delivery of Three (3) AI Workstations
Description: Tenders are sought for the Supply and Delivery of three (3) AI workstations to be situated within the Centre for Academic Practice. These AI workstations will provide for the technological infrastructure for the shared laboratory that will form part of the Research hub for Learning Innovation. Specifically, these workstations will provide appropriately configured, high end workstations capable of supporting the rapid training and fine tuning of Large Language Models (LLMs) and associated data management.

Title: Notice and Permit Processing System
Description: This notice is published retrospectively to meet transparency requirements under the Procurement Act 2023. The actual tender period closed on 07 October 2025. No further submissions will be accepted. This publication is for compliance only and links to the award notice for full visibilitySouthend-on-Sea City Council is engaging the market ahead of its procurement exercise for a secure, cloud-hosted, browser-based Notice and Permit Processing System to manage the full lifecycle of Penalty Charge Notices (PCNs), permits & visitor vouchers (virtual and physical), parking suspensions, and dispensations.The system must integrate with key agencies and platforms, support statutory compliance, improve customer access, and enable real-time enforcement operations.Overview of RequirementCloud-hosted, browser-based platform for managing PCNs, permits & visitor vouchers (virtual and physical), suspensions, dispensations, and vehicle removals.Supports full lifecycle management of parking, bus lane, moving traffic and removal of vehicles.Integrates with DVLA, TEC, TPT, payment systems, and parking hardware.Provides self-service portals for evidence, challenges, applications, and payments.Delivers automated workflows for PCN progression, appeals, and evidence packs for PCNs.Offers reporting dashboards for KPIs and operational analytics for all modules.Migrates historical data with full audit controls for PCNs and permits.Ensures compliance with existing legislation and future changes or needs.Supplies handheld devices with Bluetooth printers deployed for enforcement.Includes dedicated mobilisation support, training and fault management.

Title: Dorset School Aged Immunisation Service - Market Engagement
Description: This notice is placed as a Prior Information Notice (PIN) to inform the market of NHS England South West’s (the Commissioner’s), intention to recommission School Aged Immunisation Services in Dorset. The Commissioner would like to understand the level of provider interest in delivering these services and help inform the commissioning strategy.   To allow potential providers to reflect on the proposed services, the Commissioner has provided early indicative information as part of this notice (located within the Atamis e-procurement portal) which includes: 1.National service specification2.Schedule 2GPlease note all the above documents are in draft form and yet to be finalised. The Commissioner welcomes your feedback on these documents via return of the market engagement questionnaire. This questionnaire can be accessed through Atamis, and can be returned in Word document format via the correspondence function, or completed as a Microsoft Form. We kindly ask you to submit these by midday Wednesday 3rd December 2025.

Title: Provision of Insurance and Related Services to Trent & Dove Housing Ltd
Description: Trent & Dove Housing Ltd are looking to appoint one or more providers to deliver their Insurance and related services for Property, legal liability and other general (non-life) insurable risks.  The programme will require Insurance and related services for risks that may include but not be limited to: property damage and business interruption, employers, public, products and property owners liability, business combined/office, money, all risks, computer, contract works, group personal accident and employment practices liability. This list is to be decided at the sole discretion of Trent & Dove Housing Ltd.Suppliers will be required to have the financial ability to deliver the programme, including Insurers with a minimum rating of ‘BBB’ from standard and poor, 'B++' from AM Best, or an equivalent rating by an independent and reputable credit rating agency and approved by the bidder’s market security committee. In the case of any rating less than A-, the contracting authority will evaluate and accept the nominated insurer(s) at its sole discretion, subject to disclosure and acceptance prior to the ITT bid deadline of the bidder’s market security committee’s latest report, including written recommendation from the bidder’s market security committee.Suppliers will be assessed but not limited to the following high level criterion: - The ability to provide the Contracting Authority with a choice of suitable insurers and/or suitable cover options- A skilled and competent service team, being Client Relationship Management, Insurance Claims management, Insurance Broking / underwriting and insurable risk managers- The delivery of quality service to the Contracting Authority and our clients, including that provided to us by any third-party contractor employed by you or by the Insurer(s) you proposeFor more information about this opportunity, please visit the Delta eSourcing portal at: https://www.delta-esourcing.com/tenders/UK-UK-Burton-upon-Trent:-Insurance-services./34QH7G7D78To respond to this opportunity, please click here: https://www.delta-esourcing.com/respond/34QH7G7D78

Title: Consultancy Services to produce a Landside Development Plan at Casement Airbase, Baldonnel

The Consultants will be required to carry out a detailed infrastructure development Masterplan for the Landside of Casement Aerodrome for the next 20 years. The resulting Masterplan should consider the development of the existing Aerodrome to support current and future operations so that the capacity and efficiency of the facility can be maximised. The need is to ensure that the future infrastructure is developed in a logical, cost efficient and affordable manner.

Buyer name: Health and Social Care Professionals Council (CORU)
Title: CORU Review of Regulatory Appeals Process and Procedures
Description: CORU wish to engage the services of a supplier to review how other equivalent regulators manage appeals of regulatory decision by applicants, and make recommendations to the Professional Practice Advisory Committee on changes to the Appeals Procedures to improve the process and allow flexibility to allow management of up to 100 appeals per year. The service provider will be required to; 1. Review the regulatory appeals process of 6 to 8 other professional regulators (national and international). 2. Identify how other regulators operationally manage the appeals process, in particular in relation to appeal committee members ship, format and structure of appeals committee meetings and information provided back to the original decision maker. 3. Provide a report on the above research to the Professional Practice Advisory Committee. 4. Based on the above report, provide a second document which identifies potential changes to the CORU Appeals Procedures which could improve operational effectiveness of the process, and rationale for same which also meet the requirements of the Health and Social Care Professionals Act 2005 (as amended).
Contact Name: Health and Social Care Professionals Council (CORU)

Title: SEWER CLEANING AND INSPECTION SERVICES
Description: Rhondda Cynon Taf CBC are looking to appoint one contractor to provide Drainage Inspection Surveys including GPS locations and Cleansing services throughout the Borough. The requirements will be on a daily basis throughout each of the contract years, with a programme of works identified in advance by the Council’s Engineers. The Councils network includes a vast number of drains, gullies, sewers, and culverts.The Council require two fully operated vehicles, both vehicles will be dedicated to the service requirements, one vehicle for Drainage Inspection Surveys and one vehicle for Drain and Sewer Cleansing. Services will include routine maintenance, reactive maintenance and availability for urgent/emergency works during times of flooding/storms.

Title: IBTS BLOOD DONOR SAMPLE COLLECTION AND DELIVERY AND BLOOD COMPONENT COLLECTION AND TRANSPORT TO NBC IBTS
Description: Lots will not be awarded separately. Lot 1: This contingency service is tested two times minimum per annum. The test of the contingency requires the transport of 72 blood donor samples (1 box) to be transported from the NBC to the SNBTS Lot 2: In the event of a real donor testing contingency service being required by the IBTS it is important that the blood donor samples (2,000 – 4,000 samples) are transported to the SNBTS as soon as possible so that the SNBTS can complete the testing required by the IBTS as the results are required to allow for the release of blood and blood products to the hospitals. Lot 3 (a) The IBTS on occasion imports blood components from other blood transfusion services to meet patients’ needs. This process is managed by the IBTS medical team, the Red Cell Immunohaematology Laboratory (RCI) and the Scientific Support and Component Development (SSCD) departments. These units must be transported under appropriate temperature and environmental conditions in a timely manner. (b) The IBTS on occasion imports bulk blood for stock reasons using IBTS vehicles and IBTS drivers. These importations require customs and logistical support in person accompanying the driver on both the outward and inward journey. The timeline for notification of the requirement for this in person support for importation can vary. It may be 24 hours from initial contact from IBTS to delivery of imported components to the IBTS. The IBTS provides transport containers according to internal requirements and differ between LOT 1 and 2 and Lot 3. Transport boxes may contain infectious materials.

Title: Bawtry Town Hall Toilet Refurbishment
Description: The Town Council is looking to refurbish the public toilets within the Town Hall community centre with the removal of all existing sanitary ware and a revised layout to be installed including one disabled toilet, 1 female toilet with 3 toilets and associated washbasins and 1 male toilets with 2 toilets, 2 urinals and associated washbasins. Grant funding is being sought and this may affect the commencement. Contractors should refer to the layout document included in the tender documents.The tender should be submitted in electronic format.All electronic tender documents/electronic media are to be addressed to theclerk@bawtrytowncouncil.gov.uk and annotated with "TENDER DOCUMENTS NOT TO BE OPENED BEFORE 5pm Friday 9th January 2026. The Council reserves the right to discount any tender received in contravention of this instruction.Tenders are to remain open for acceptance for a period of 90 days.Lot 1: The Town Council is looking to refurbish the public toilets within the Town Hall community centre with the removal of all existing sanitary ware and a revised layout to be installed including one disabled toilet, 1 female toilet with 3 toilets and associated washbasins and 1 male toilets with 2 toilets, 2 urinals and associated washbasins.
