Buyer name: Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency
Buyer Category: Agencies and non-departmental public bodies, Central healthcare organisations
Title: Digital Solution for Global Dispatch, Inventory Management and Sale of Biological Reference Materials
Description: The Agency is seeking to let a contract for a three-year period, with two twelve-month optional extensions (for a total possible five-year contract term) to one Supplier.The Agency is seeking to let a contract with a phased approach to deliverables. There will be a Phase I consisting of mandatory works, which, at the discretion of MHRA may lead-in to a second Phase of works. The MHRA manufactures Biological Reference Materials (“standards”) that support the harmonisation of biological medicines and ensure the accuracy of diagnostic tests. Such standards are produced and distributed from the MHRA’s Science Campus based in Hertfordshire, UK and are distributed globally via the NIBSC website. To support this essential function, the Agency is seeking to replace its legacy dispatch system, Assist4, which is scheduled for retirement by December 2026.The MHRA also produces British Pharmacopoeia Chemical Reference Substances (BPCRS) which is currently contracted out to LGC who also manage despatch through their in-house dispatch system and so not in scope of this requirement.The immediate priority is to secure a modern, scalable dispatch solution that ensures continuity of logistics and shipping operations and integrates effectively with MHRA’s existing inventory system also known as “Ingenica 360” that is built on the MS dynamics platform.While the dispatch functionality described above is the core requirement, the Agency strongly encourages modular solutions that can be extended in future phases to support inventory management, trade compliance, forecasting, courier booking, and integration with its e-commerce web-based platform. This modular approach aligns with MHRA’s long-term goal to streamline operations across inventory management, sales and dispatch, alongside its Manufacturing Resource Planning (MRP) lifecycle.MHRA remains open to innovative approaches that meet its evolving operational needs.

Title: e-ITT for the provision of Dudley Avenue Recreation Ground – Access and Open Space Enhancement Works
Description: e-ITT for the provision of Dudley Avenue Recreation Ground – Access and Open Space Enhancement Works Closing Date for Submission of Tenders 12.00 NOON, 12 DECEMBER 2025 To be returned electronically via the Council's e-tendering solution "Pro-Contract" hosted on the South East Business Portal (SEBP) New Forest District Council (NFDC) wish to engage a Contractor to undertake landscape works for the project referred to as Ho4 – Dudley Avenue Recreation Ground - Access and Open Space Enhancement works. The site is existing Public Open Space that will be further improved for informal recreation in accordance with New Forest District Council Mitigation Strategy: Mitigation for Recreational Impacts SPD 2021 and Infrastructure Delivery Plan. The project will provide a new all-year round accessible footpath to the perimeter of the site and provide new seating and enhanced landscaping and planting works All correspondence is via the Councils e-tendering portal ProContract hosted on the South East Business Portal (SEBP).Keywords:Open Space Enhancements

Medway Council identified a need to target support for Domestic Abuse victims with additional needs and vulnerabilities within the community. This will increase the support available in Medway and provide support to people with additional vulnerabilities who often are excluded from services.For more information about this opportunity, please visit the Delta eSourcing portal at: https://www.delta-esourcing.com/tenders/UK-UK-Chatham:-Domestic-services./Q99E23SYU6To respond to this opportunity, please click here: https://www.delta-esourcing.com/respond/Q99E23SYU6

Title: AT1453 Community Carers Support Service
Description: To provide a face to face service for carers within the community.  The proposed service will deliver information, advice, navigation, and practical and emotional support for unpaid carers aged 18 and above. It will play a key role in improving early identification, wellbeing, and resilience among carers, while ensuring access to appropriate support at different points in their caring journey.Keywords:Carers Support Service, Community Carers Support

Title: Pre-Qualification Questionnaire for the Provision of Mystery Passenger Survey Services
Description: The Authority intends to engage a service provider to deliver continuous Mystery Passenger Surveys across multiple modes of public transport. The Services shall include all, but are not limited to, the following survey types: • Bus Service Mystery Passenger Surveys; Bus Station Mystery Passenger Surveys; Light Rail Service Mystery Passenger Surveys; Rail Service Mystery Passenger Surveys; Rail Station Mystery Passenger Surveys; Dublin Bus Head Office Mystery Passenger Surveys; and Static Bus Stop Mystery Passenger Surveys. The Services shall include all necessary management and administration, survey design, data collection, data processing and analysis and reporting of performance data. At each stage it is paramount the research is carried out using a rigorous method of quality control. Surveys shall be conducted continuously and reported on a quarterly basis. Results of each survey should be available to the Authority and to the relevant Operator post quality checking from the team, to allow any queries on the data to be raised. Circa 2,500 individual Mystery Passenger Surveys are required to be completed each quarter. The central aim of the Services is to provide data that can be used to manage Operator performance and allow the Authority to assign target service levels which can then be used by contract managers and Operators to effectively monitor and improve customer experience. The survey results are subject to a high level of scrutiny and its methodology and quality is required to be robust. The mystery passenger survey is a critical piece of work for the Authority and various transport contracts that rely on its results.

Title: Automatic Doors, Roller Shutters and Barriers Servicing and Maintenance

Buyer name: University Hospitals of Morecambe Bay NHS Foundation Trust
Title: Clinical Waste Management
Description: Contractual ArrangementsUniversity Hospitals Morecambe Bay NHS Foundation Trust (UHMB) will act as the ‘lead’ organisation in terms of managing the tender process on behalf of the Trusts involved within the Northern Consortium. However, any final contract implementation, on-boarding and ongoing contract management will be the responsibility of the individual Trusts.Each individual Trust reserves the right to commence the contract in accordance with their own required timescales and, each individual Trust reserves the right not to commence a contract at all.The Northern Clinical Waste Consortium (“NCWC”) which is made up of a number of Acute and Community NHS Trusts “Member Organisations” Acute NHS Trusts1.Bradford Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust 2.Harrogate and District NHS Foundation Trust 3.York and Scarborough Teaching Hospitals 4.University Hospitals of Morecambe Bay NHS Foundation Trust 5.North Cumbria Integrated Care NHS Trust 6.South Tees Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust – Friarage 7.North Tees and Hartlepool NHS Trust8.Northumbria Healthcare Facilities Management Community NHS Trusts1.Bradford Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust 2.Harrogate and District NHS Foundation Trust 3.York and Scarborough Teaching Hospitals 4.University Hospitals of Morecambe Bay NHS Foundation Trust 5.North Cumbria Integrated Care NHS Trust 6.Humber Teaching NHS Foundation Trust 7.NTW Solutions 8.Tees, Esk and Wear Valleys NHS Foundation Trust 9.Northumbria Healthcare Facilities Management 10.North East Ambulance Service NHS Trust 11.Westmorland and Furness CouncilStatement of ObjectivesThe Trusts wish to enter into contract with a suitably qualified provider(s) to develop an innovative and practical solution for:“Providing an efficient, cost effective and timely service for safe handling, transport, disposal of clinical waste from the participating Trust’s sites to its final point of disposal”It is envisaged that the contract period will be for THREE years, with an option to extend up to an additional 24 months based upon Trust requirements.Key Requirements of the ServiceThe Trusts wish to procure a suitably qualified provider(s) to manage a Clinical Waste Service. The aim is to provide value for money whilst maintaining and improving the existing service and enabling developments to meet new service demands and changing legislation.Offers received from bidders following issue of an Invitation to Tender by the Trust’s should maximise opportunities for savings in procurement and deliver first class technical solutions.The Trust’s wish to engage with a contractor(s) who, from the commencement of the contract is able to provide services to all Acute and Community sites within the Northern Consortium or separately for Acute or Community Sites in accordance with the LOTS outlined below:LOTLOT Description1Acute Hospital Sites2Community Sites3Both Acute Hospital and Community SitesKey Service ObjectivesIt is envisaged that outputs to be required contractually in the contract will include, but not be limited to:·Maintain full compliance with all regulatory requirements and applicable codes of practice·Provide an efficient, cost effective and timely service for safe handling, transport and disposal of clinical waste from the Trust(s) sites to its final point of disposal·Work with the Trust(s) to ensure a ‘zero to landfill’ target is achieved for the life of the contract·Recover value from the Trust(s) waste to generate rebated funds to the Trust(s), allowing funds to be re-invested in the Trust(s) in projects such as (but not limited to) further waste reduction, re-use, recycling projects etc.·Support the Trust(s) in its target to increase the amount of waste currently recycled ·Support the Trust(s) to train staff in best practice waste management principles, to reduce waste and improve the Trust(s) Environmental performance. This will include support for training sessions, awareness events and competitions.

Buyer name: Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency
Buyer Category: Agencies and non-departmental public bodies, Central healthcare organisations
Title: Animal Management Database
Description: The Agency is seeking to establish a working solution that supports the development of an Animal Management Database—a strategic investment for the MHRA. This system will enable real-time electronic record-keeping and reporting to strengthen compliance with ASPA, streamline operational workflows, and uphold high standards of animal welfare through integrated digital infrastructure and competency tracking.MHRA seeks a partner to deliver a comprehensive solution that meets both immediate and long-term needs for animal facility management. The new system must support secure data capture, real-time tracking, and reporting across multiple sites, while ensuring compliance with Home Office licensing and audit standards. It should accommodate both high-frequency operational data, such as daily health checks and procedure logs, as well as long-term archival records, including historical logs, training certifications, and compliance documentation. Handling of sensitive data must be robust, with appropriate access controls and retention policies in place.

Buyer name: Health and Social Care Professionals Council (CORU)
Title: CORU - Legal Services to Support Appeals Management
Description: CORU wish to engage the services of a supplier to provide legal support to manage the appeals process, with the aim of decisions to be made on all appeals cases pending as of 31 December 2025 (170 approximately) in 2026. The person or persons providing the services should be available provide a service to the CORU Appeals Team (2 persons) in the CORU offices at least two days and week, and in a hybrid environment for two days (total 4 days a week) for 46 weeks. The service provider will be required to; 1. Support operational management of appeals including scheduling of appeals, liaising with appeals committee members, legal assessors and appellants, organising training for appeals committee members. 2. Review appeals applications to ensure documents are properly completed and valid. 3. Complete monthly reporting on appeals cases heard, outcomes and progress.

Title: Tenemental Property Study
Description: Dundee’s private sector tenemental housing stock comprises historic sandstone buildings and post-war flatted developments, forming a significant part of the city's residential infrastructure. These properties face challenges including aging structures, energy inefficiency, and non-compliance with modern safety standards. Through funding from the UK Government's Community Regeneration Partnership, Dundee City Council aims to develop a strategic overview of tenemental properties requiring investment in building fabric repairs and ongoing maintenance to ensure quality accommodation standards.Lot 1: The Council invites consultants with expertise in housing, surveying, and property repair to conduct a strategic assessment of tenemental properties within Dundee. This includes site inspections and desktop reviews, culminating in an initial report covering -City-wide count and classification of tenemental properties by type and location. -Analysis of tenure types, occupancy levels, and tenant turnover. -Overview of Registered Social Landlords' roles. -High-level assessment of building and living space conditions compared to other cities. -Evaluation of existing property factoring and feasibility of mandatory factoring.

Title: Adult Cycle Training - Request for Quotations
Description: The Active Travel Team of Cambridgeshire County Council are looking for an adult cycle training provider that can deliver sessions across the five districts (Cambridge, East Cambridgeshire, Huntingdonshire, Fenland and South Cambridgeshire). To include the below:- Delivery of adult cycle training in both individual and group formats for varying levels of experience. This could include a beginner with zero cycling experience to an intermediate level with knowledge of how to cycle but may lack knowledge of how to cycle on roads.- A booking system with capability of pre-screening to prioritise minority groups including women, elderly, ethnic minorities and carers.- Delivery of adult cycle training to circa 388 residents.- An inventory of bicycles and safety equipment that can be used during the sessions.Please refer to the attached specification document for further details.

Title: Temporary Labour for GWR
Description: At certain times throughout the year, GWR requires temporary staff to support with either routine station operations or specific planned events. Increased footfall during peak seasons is often reflected in an increased seasonal demand for temporary staff, whereas business as usual demands (eg to cover sickness or roster gaps) can fluctuate throughout the year, requiring a responsive temporary workforce that can flex with our needs.  These temporary staff are specifically required to support with the following functions/roles:•Gateline•Station Assistance•General Customer Service•Events•Projects/PossessionsRole Profiles will be shared during the tender exercise.ObjectivesThe temporary labour contract must ensure continuity of operations, provide support for special events and meet project deadlines by supplementing the permanent GWR workforce with qualified temporary personnel.Flexibility and responsiveness is essential to enable fulfilment of short-notice requests for either single shifts or longer-term cover, and proactive forecasting and modelling is required to ensure good coverage for pre-planned special events and projects/possessions across the network.  Scope of ServicesServices will be requested as required, with forecasting and modelling taking place where possible, but with short-term requests required to ensure good coverage of business as usual operations. Job roles required are Gateline, Station Assistance, general customer service, and support during events or projects/possessions.The number of personnel required to support with the GWR operation may vary significantly but is estimated to be between 10,000-15,000 hours per quarter (based on 2024/25 figures). Expected working hours could fall anywhere between 06:00-23:00 (dependent on region, station and role), and shifts should generally be between 7 and 10 hours in duration. Temporary labour assignments, particularly ad hoc requests, could be located at any station across the GWR network, see GWR Route Map in the Appendix. Stations that annually have special events and will require a volume of forecasted support include Cheltenham Spa, Bath Spa, Henley-on-Thames, Reading, Castle Cary and Newquay.The duration of engagement could vary significantly, based on the role, location and reason for request. For short-notice sickness cover the requirement could be for just one or two shifts. Longer-term sickness coverage, or support with filling a roster due to other absence, could mean an engagement of many weeks or even months. A special event or possession, dependent on scale and duration, could require a booking of three or four consecutive shifts, up to a few weeks or even longer. Temporary labour support at GWR is often required more at weekends (particularly Sunday) than during the week, so the labour provider should note that coverage of weekend shifts is a key requirement. Specific tasks and responsibilities are outlined in the Role Profiles included in the Appendix, with training provided where necessary, and temporary staff should also be expected to comply with any reasonable request from a Station Manager.

Title: Electrical - General electrical works
Description: •Solar panel inverters should be inspected and maintained at least once a year by a qualified professional. This annual check-up is to ensure the inverter is functioning correctly, identify potential issues early, and prevent costly repairs. A more frequent inspection (e.g., bi-annually) may be necessary in some areas of the WRC which will be left to the discretion of the inspector. This is based on potential high pollution levels and weather conditions on the roof. •Manufacturer's specific recommendations for our inverter models should always be referred to and referenced in documentation, as they may have unique guidelines for maintenance and inspection•All inspections and maintenance performed by qualified professionals. We request members of our in-house engineering team oversee as much of the inspections as possible so they can understand what to look for on routine inspections of these plant areas.•A full visual inspection of every solar panel will be needed to highlight damaged or faulty panels. •As well as inspections we expect full electrical certs to be issued with each yearly inspection. •We would also need a budget cost to come in the same day the solar panels are being cleaned twice a year to isolate them the process and re energise once the clean is complete.  This opportunity has been distributed on adamprocure.co.uk

Title: Caledonia Housing Association - Landscape Maintenance 2026 - 2028 (East Site 4)

Title: Upper Thurne Construction Works - Package 2
Description: This procurement covers the design and construction of 3 x pumping stations, namely Martham pumping station, Potter Heigham pumping station and Brograve pumping station.  It also allows for the optionality of adding one additional similar pumping station site namely Somerton South Pumping Station and Culvert or Repps pumping station at a future date. Each of these sites has an existing pumping station which will need to be decommissioned.  Any instruction for one of the two optional sites is expected to be within 12 months of the Contract Date.The value is estimated at £8-£12million for the initial 3 sites with up to a further £6million for the fourth site depending on works required.  These figures are exclusive of VAT.  These works are to be funded from Environment Agency Grant in Aid. The works and its objectives are entirely consistent to ensure compliance with the BIDB statutory duties as a Section 28g body under the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981 (as amended).The scope of the works:Design and construction for the 3 pumping stations.  Design is limited to the following design tasks (Refer Section S300 of the Scope)Telemetry systemExternal lighting Control kiosk including HVAC Motor Control Centre and full electrical system design including Functional Design SpecificationStop log systems and non return / control valvesDucting and draw pit numbers and dimensionsPrecast Concrete Units MCC support frameTemporary works including relevant licences, permissions and consentsAssociated civil, mechanical and electrical worksIntegration with existing water infrastructureTesting, commissioning and handover to operationsSectional CompletionDecommissioning of existing 3 pumping stationsPotential for all of the above for 4th site.Bidders that express interest following the publication of this Tender Notice will be invited to attend an accompanied group visit incorporating Martham, Potter Heigham and Brograve.   Two dates will be available (as detailed below), and each bidder is required to attend only one of these sessions.  Attendance will be limited to one vehicle and a maximum of 2 representatives per organisation. The vehicle must be a 4x4 to enable access to these sites:Tuesday 25th November 2025Wednesday 26th November 2025All questions and answers raised during the 2 site visit days will be documented and shared with all Tenderers via the eTender portal.The Water Management Alliance (WMA) will oversee this procurement on behalf of the Broads Internal Drainage Board working with Turner & Townsend as advisors.

Title: Strategic Flood Risk Assessment
Description: The Council is seeking to appoint a suitably qualified consultant team to undertake a Strategic Flood Risk assessment  (SFRA) - Level 1 with an option for a Level 2 Assessment to support the new Local Plan, in line with national requirements. The SFRA will assess: •the risk from all sources of flooding•the cumulative impact that development or changing land use would have on the risk of flooding•the effect of climate change on riskThe SFRA should identify:•opportunities to reduce the causes and impacts of flooding•any land likely to be needed for current and future flood risk management features and structuresThe study should be consistent with requirements set out in the Government’s National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) and Planning Practice Guidance (PPG) and any updates as appropriate.

Title: DLSITT1077 - Diamond-II Thin Septum Magnets
Description: Located on the Harwell Science and Innovation Campus in Oxfordshire, Diamond Light Source (DLS) is a leading-edge facility for science, engineering and innovation. Diamond allows researchers from academia and industry to investigate the structure and behaviour of the world around us at the atomic and molecular level. To continue delivering the world-changing science that Diamond enables, the facility is being upgraded to Diamond-II, a co-ordinated programme of development that combines a major machine upgrade with new instruments and complementary improvements to optics,detectors, sample environment and delivery capabilities, and computing, as well as integrated and correlative methods. This will be transformative in speed and spatial resolution and will offer users streamlined access to enhanced instruments for life and physical sciences.The scope of this contract is to carry out the detailed design, manufacture, quality control, testing and delivery of a pre-series in-vacuum thin septum magnet and power supply, and two production magnets and power supplies as detailed in the specification.

Title: RFT for the Provision of Mechanical Services Framework at MEDITE Europe DAC ‘25
Description: Medite Europe DAC are seeking tender submissions from suitably qualified engineering companies with extensive experience in the MDF / wood processing industry for appointment to a Framework Agreement for a range of small to medium sized Mechanical works at their plant in Redmondstown, Clonmel, Co. Tipperary, E91 V584. Types of works: 1) Annual Large-scale shutdown works 2) Fortnightly shutdown works 3) Hourly rate works related to projects An example of the type of work involved is listed but not limited to the table below No. Maintenance Activity Performance Characteristics 1. Routine Maintenance General basic maintenance services to mechanical plant + equipment Activities that are conducted while equipment and systems are in service these are predictable and can be scheduled. Generally, these are the activities scheduled on a time-based schedule derived from preventive or predictive maintenance strategies. Some examples are visual inspections, cleaning, functional tests, and measurement of operating quantities, lubrication and oil tests. 2. Maintenance Testing Activities that involve using test equipment to assess condition in an offline state. These activities are predictable and can be scheduled and budgeted. They may be scheduled on a time or meter basis but may be planned to coincide with scheduled equipment outages. Since these activities are predictable. Some examples are governor alignments and balanced and unbalanced gate. 3. Downday Schedule Activities that involve assessing the condition of equipment after unusual events, such as equipment failure/ repair/replacement or when equipment deterioration is suspected. Therefore replacement, remedial works or modifications may need to be conducted in order to ensure the equipment is operational after the schedule downtime period has lapsed.

Buyer Category: Agencies and non-departmental public bodies, Central healthcare organisations
Title: HSE DML, HSE Pathfinder Decarbonisation Programme; Decarbonisation and Energy Upgrade of Regional Hospital Mullingar Mechanical Reserved Specialist.
Description: The project involves service and fabric upgrades to the main hospital buildings at Regional Hospital, Mullingar, a new Energy Centre and associated infrastructure site works. Works will be carried out within a live hospital environment which must remain operational throughout. Works include replacement of existing flat roof finishes. Installation of roof level Photovoltaic arrays over new and existing roof finishes. Installation of edge protection systems. Installation of large plant and replacement of existing plant. Works within existing plantrooms and hospital building including installation of new cabling and electrical boards. Construction of a new energy centre including new heat pumps, ESB substation, transformer rooms and client switch room, with associated plant and equipment install and connection to new ESB incoming mains. Site works including installation of a new MV ring main including civil engineering/trench works.

Title: Adult Pathways  Phase 1
Description: The Adult Pathway caters for vulnerable single homeless people and contributes directly to the Council’s ambitions by being a key resource for preventing homelessness and reducing rough sleeping and by providing a safe place to access support that addresses their needs. The support provided helps people to get on a pathway to a sustainable home by enabling access to services they need in ways that work for them. By providing accommodation for homeless single people, the Pathway reduces the need for increasingly difficult to procure expensive statutory (and unsupported) Temporary Accommodation, and for reactive, intensive public services such as A&amp;E, Police or Adult Social Care services.Keywords:accommodation , homeless, support for single homeless people

Title: Somerset Housing First - Complex Needs Housing Pathways (East Area)
Description: The Housing First model is designed to support the most vulnerable individuals within this cohort. It offers a person-centred, holistic approach that prioritises immediate access to secure, long-term housing without preconditions. Through intensive, tailored support, Housing First aims to improve engagement, promote stability, and enable individuals to sustain their tenancies and rebuild their lives.This commissioning initiative seeks to deliver a high-impact Somerset Housing First service in Somerset for individuals with complex needs who have experienced long-term or repeat homelessness. By sourcing and providing stable housing as the foundation for recovery and inclusion, the scheme aims to reduce reliance on crisis services, improve health and wellbeing outcomes, and promote long-term tenancy sustainment.

Title: LI3542C MU PQQ For the Provision of Subscriptions to a Service Providing Financial Real-time Data and News and Financial Datasets
Description: Maynooth University aims to maintain seamless access to global financial real-time data, news, and comprehensive financial datasets to continue the enhancement of its academic and professional programs. The chosen provider must deliver secure, scalable solutions tailored for higher education, supporting multiple dedicated terminals within the university’s financial laboratory. Suppliers are invited to express interest if they have a strong track record in delivering subscriptions for educational financial data services—including specific solutions and support for Irish higher education institutions.

Title: Call For Tender for provision of Hot Meals under the School Meals Scheme to Goresbridge NS Roll No. 19944O

Title: Proc-25-3124 - Water Management Risk Assessments
Description: The Scottish Police Authority (known as the “the Authority”) requires a Contract in place for water management risk assessments to be carried out. The Authority is tendering this opportunity to appoint a suitably experienced and competent Contractor.Lot 1: The Scottish Police Authority (known as the “the Authority”) requires a Contract in place for water management risk assessments to be carried out. The Authority is tendering this opportunity to appoint a suitably experienced and competent Contractor.Under the Health & Safety at Work Regulations (1974), The Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations (1999), and the Control of Substances Hazardous to Health Regulations 2002 (COSHH), concerning risk from exposure to Legionella bacteria, the Authority has a duty of care towards their users (e.g. staff, officers, members of the public) to protect them from contracting Legionella and other microbial infections through providing a safe water supply system fit for human consumption and culinary purposes throughout their premises and estates. This duty of care also extends to the susceptibility of the local population to the risk of exposure to the Legionella bacteria.The Authority currently has a requirement for circa 330 Buildings across Police Scotland’s Estate covering the whole of Scotland including island locations. This list will be updated during the Contract period and is not a fixed site list, or amount of properties and can be increased or reduced during the Contract term.The Contractor shall carry out ACoP L8 legionella Water risk assessment services and Written Schemes for controlling risk, in line with HSE ACoP L8 and BS 8680:2020 Water quality – Water safety plans – Code of Practice, referred to in this document as BS 8680:2020, or any superseding codes of practice. The requirement may include but not limited to:The identification of systems of riskThe review of existing risk assessmentsProduction of up to date Schematics of the water systemAppraisal of system condition including accessible equipmentManagement of Log BooksWater Management reviewProvision of a Legionella Risk AssessmentProduction of Written SchemeAnalysis of Drinking Water systemsSupply on-going technical advice on compliance with current legislation and codes of practice including definition of responsibilities and duties of Responsible Person.An Online/web-based portal provided by the organisation will be used by Contractor to upload and store the Control Manuals, Log Books with WRA reports and any associated files to allow to have a login access to Organisation account with a file download functionality

Buyer name: The Charity Commission For England And Wales
Title: Charity Commission Digital Transformation Programme
Description: The Charity Commission Strategy 2024-2029 (https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/charity-commission-strategy-2024-2029) sets out the ambition to embrace technological innovation and strengthen how data is used across the organisation. The overarching vision for the programme is to:1) Strengthen Public Trust & Deliver Meaningful Impact2) Create simple Services for Smarter Regulation3) Empower People & Build Organisational ExcellenceThis vision will be achieved by: - Improving user experience for charities and their trustees - Using technology to enable better use of resources and expertise - Improving the quality of data and building trust in it - Being an intelligent, joined up regulator working with government departments to integrate services The programme goes beyond technology to a pure transformation, considering business processes and ways of working to provide a truly transformed user-centric set of services for trustees and charities across England and Wales. All of our digital services and casework activities are in scope of this programme, further information of these services can be found on our GOV.UK web site https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/charity-commission/about/about-our-services From a technology perspective, all software runs on Microsoft Azure, and our core case management platform is built on Dynamics 365. We currently use Liferay as a Digital Experience Platform. We are building new digital service front-ends using Spring Boot. All digital services must meet GDS standards. The first opportunity under the programme is now open for responses, see https://redirect.contractawardservice.crowncommercial.gov.uk/digital-outcomes/opportunities/opportunity-details/project/69378  for further information.

Title: PP-10173 Co-op Academies Trust Catering
Description: Co-op Academies Trust is a multi-academy trust with schools located in West Yorkshire, Greater Manchester, Merseyside, and Staffordshire. Their portfolio of schools includes around 38 academies across these areas, serving primary, secondary, and special schools, as well as a college of which 32 will be involved in this tender.The trust currently receives catering provision from the local authority as well as other privately owned incumbents.At the sole discretion of the Trust any future schools that the Trust may incorporate into the Trust will also be added to the contract. Any additional schools will co-terminate to the end same end date of the initial contract.The proposed contract will be for the outsourced provision of catering services to the Client. It is the Client’s expectation that the Successful Bidder shall be responsible for the operation of the catering function including employment and management of staff, supply of foodstuffs, consumables and light equipment where required and preparing and serving appropriate meals. The Supplier will also be expected to provide hospitality at certain school events both during and outside of school core hours.  The Client will retain responsibility for payment of utilities and the operation and maintenance of core catering equipment and facilities. The Successful bidder will provide a range of good quality, nutritious, attractively presented meals for pupils and staff, that comply with Government’s minimum nutritional and food based standards for the educational sector. Meals should reflect growth in healthy eating trends and promote uptake. The Successful Bidder shall establish effective management and operational level communication systems at all levels regarding the catering service with customers that include; School management, parents, and pupils. In addition, the Successful Bidder will also be responsible for all legal and health and safety & food safety requirements in delivering the catering services. Further information on the Client’s requirements can be found in the tender package.The Contract period will be for 3 years initially, with the option to extend for two further one-year periods at the discretion of the Client.The Contract is split into  Lots.

The successful partner must deliver consistent, high-quality standards and take pride in maintaining safe, hygienic environments for young learners and school staff.Strong client relationships are essential – the contractors must be responsive, be articulate, be communicative, and be committed to collaborative working within all of the schools.Scope: Daily cleaning across six primary schoolsContract Start Date: 28th March 2026Suppliers will be assessed against the specific objectives of the new contract through the following stages:-Selection and Shortlisting-Invitation to Tender and Shortlisting for Presentation-Presentation of Proposal to the Federation (Authority)-Reference Checking

Title: THE PROVISION OF NO SECOND  IN THE LONDON BOROUGH OF WALTHAM FOREST
Description: The London Borough of Waltham Forest invites suitably qualified and experienced providers to tender for the delivery of a No Second Night Out Accommodation Based Project (NSNO-ABP). This service will provide short-term, supported accommodation for single adults who are currently sleeping rough, with the aim of facilitating rapid assessment, stabilisation, and transition into longer-term housing.Service Objectives•Provide immediate, safe, and supported accommodation for rough sleepers•Conduct holistic assessments within 72 hours of entry•Develop personalised support and resettlement plans•Facilitate access to health, social care, and housing services•Support residents to transition into sustainable accommodationTarget Group•Adults aged 18+ who are rough sleeping•Individuals with complex needs including mental health, substance misuse, or offending history•Referrals accepted only via the Council’s Rough Sleeping Coordinator through Pathway Planning meetingsAccommodation Requirements•14 self-contained or semi-self-contained units•Communal space for meals and social interaction•Office space for staff and confidential meetings•Secure access and CCTVKeywords:No Second Night Out

Title: Cladding & Building Safety Inspections (CPU7402)

The inspections will assess compliance with relevant fire safety and building regulations, identify potential risks, and support the Council’s obligations under the Building Safety Act 2022 and Fire Safety (England) Regulations 2022. This service supports the Council’s duty to maintain a robust and auditable fire safety management system.Keywords:Building Safety Surveys, Building Cladding Inspections, Building Safety Inspections, Building Cladding Surveys, Building Safety Act

Title: NWSSP Roll Cages
Description: NHS Wales Shared Services Partnership (NWSSP), hosted by Velindre NHS Trust, provides a wide range of essential support services to Health Boards and NHS Trusts across Wales. The organisation plays a key role in delivering efficient, value-driven, and sustainable shared services on behalf of NHS Wales, supporting the overall delivery of healthcare to patients across the country.Procurement Services within NWSSP is responsible for sourcing, purchasing, and supply chain management across the Welsh NHS. The service ensures the availability of high-quality goods and materials through effective procurement frameworks, driving best value and compliance with public sector standards.Supply Chain Services operate regional distribution centres across Wales to manage the storage, picking, and delivery of medical and non-medical consumables to NHS sites. This ensures a reliable and responsive logistics network that supports day-to-day clinical and operational needs.Laundry Services operate four regional areas within Wales, providing essential linen and laundry services to Health Boards and Trusts, maintaining high standards of hygiene, safety, and service quality across the NHS Wales estate.This tender seeks to establish a contract for the supply of robust, fit-for-purpose, and durable roll cages that meet the operational requirements of both the Supply Chain and Laundry Services departments. The successful supplier will provide products built to the specified technical standards, supporting safe, efficient, and reliable material handling and logistics across NHS Wales.

Title: Provision of the Supply, Delivery, and Installation of a Scanning Electron Microscope to DCU
Description: Tenders are sought for the supply of equipment to be located in the Core Technologies Unit as an open access instrument. The Key features of the instrument are Field Emission Gun with a low landing voltage and in-lens detectors. Material analysis is the main thrust of the instrument, so we are interested in Energy Dispersive X-Ray Spectroscopy (EDS) and Electron Backscatter Diffraction (EBDS) detectors. DCU would also be looking to expand the capabilities of the instrument over time, so modularity would be an advantage, as we would charge neutralisation features such as various chamber pressure. We are looking to include service contracts as part of the package.

Title: Brecknock and Sport & Social Club Demolition
Description: Cardiff and Vale University Health Board (CAVUHB) is one of the largest NHS organisations in the UK which provides day to day health services to a population of around 472,400 people living in Cardiff and the Vale of Glamorgan.Over recent years, the Capital, Estates and Facilities (CEF) Department have invested in Retail Catering Services to ensure they support and complement Clinical Services. Patients, staff, students and visitors require access to high quality catering services which meet their demands, dietary needs and provide value for money.Brecknock House is a nine  storey + roof former accommodation block converted to offices with two internal concrete stair case, two flights per floor and two electric passenger lifts and a service tunnel  accessed via one of the staircases. (See  plans within the tender pack. )Brecknock house is located within the University of Wales Hospital Cardiff CF14 4XW and is accessed off Heath Park Way. The front elevation is shown in specification master attachment.The project comprises the demolition of the former accommodation / office  block including the ground floor level slab, the removal of the foundations and reinstatement of the disturbed area in hardcore to form a new car parking area all levels to match existing carpark accepting the natural gradient of the location. Note ! We have an agreement with Cardiff City Council on weekend working Saturday 8.00am to 1.00pm only and No work on a Sunday. No overtime will be paid unless agreed prior to the event with the Project Manager. Note! The elevation drawing within the tender documentation shows Carmarthen House however they are the same design except Brecknock House does not have the flat attached.The sports and social club is located within the University of Wales Hospital Cardiff CF14 4XW and is accessed off Heath Park Way for the rear doors and The Gateway via a pedestrian walkway to the front entrance. The project comprises the demolition of the sports and social club including the toilet block and Union office, both under a concrete waffle constructed canopy, the ground floor level slab and a swimming pool, the removal of the foundations and reinstatement of the disturbed area in hardcore to form a new car parking area all levels to match existing. Note ! we have an agreement in place with Cardiff City Council that Saturday working is between 8.00am and 1.00pm with no works on a Sunday without 28 days notice. No overtime will be sanctioned unless agreed with the Project Manager prior to the event. The Gym room within the sports and social club has a part “sprung wood” Floor with rubber gym matts in various places mirrors on the wall, caution when working in this area.

Description: Medway Council’s Education and SEND Division is looking to commission Medway’s Special Educational Needs and Disabilities support, advice, and information service (SENDIASS) for children, young people, and their parents / carers.The Local Authority invites applications from suitably qualified providers who can deliver:•A high-quality service which improves our families understanding and enables them to make informed choices and participate in decisions. •Legally based information, impartial advice and confidential support delivered primarily via website, social media, telephone, email, and face-to-face support from a trained Information Advice Support (IAS) practitioner on request.Contract is anticipated to commence on Monday 1st April 2026.To view this notice, please click here: https://www.kentbusinessportal.org.uk/delta/viewNotice.html?noticeId=994163675

Title: Market Engagement Event - Recommissioning Housing-Related Support for People Experiencing Multiple Disadvantage in Sheffield
Description: Sheffield City Council is inviting providers to a Market Engagement Event to explore the opportunity to co-design and deliver a new integrated service model that brings together five existing services into one cohesive, person-centred offer. This ambitious redesign will be commissioned through an Alliance Contract, enabling a consortium of providers to work collaboratively to support individuals facing housing insecurity and overlapping challenges such as poor mental health, substance use, domestic abuse, and contact with the criminal justice system. The new service will commence delivery in April 2027. Our Vision A trauma-informed, strengths-based, and inclusive service that: • Offers wrap-around support across all levels of homelessness prevention and multiple disadvantage. • Embeds peer support and lived experience in design, delivery, and evaluation. • Provides flexible pathways for young people, adults, and those with complex needs. • Delivers recovery-focused interventions through assertive outreach, drop-ins, and community-based hubs. What’s Changing? • From: Five separate contracts with individual providers. • To: One integrated service delivered by an alliance of providers with shared objectives, outcomes, risks, and rewards. • Commissioning Model: Alliance Contract with collaborative governance and co-produced service design following consortia bidding. Who Should Attend? • Providers with experience in housing support, mental health, substance use, domestic abuse, or criminal justice. • Organisations interested in forming or joining a consortium to deliver a multi-functional, city-wide service. This Event will take place on Tuesday 9th December 2025 10am to 11:30am on Microsoft Teams, if you are interested in registering for this event please contact adam.elwis@sheffield.gov.uk or send a message through the YORtender portal.

Title: Land Enabling Works
Description: ORE Catapult has established a cutting-edge testing and demonstration facility in Aberdeen, named the Floating Offshore Wind Innovation Centre (FLOWIC) based within the Energy Transition Zone.ORE Catapult is committed to enhancing its capabilities by extending its capacity for testing mooring lines, a crucial component in floating offshore wind (FOW) applications. Title: The Provision of two Children’s Care homes in Cardiff
Description: The service to be provided is residential care for Children or Young People (CYP) aged 11-17 (with the option to vary if demand dictates), within a Cardiff Council-owned children’s home, placed after an assessment of their needs by Cardiff Council. These services will be provided in a manner that best safeguards and promotes the welfare of the Child or Young Person in respect of whom the Services are provided. Children and young people will need to be supported using the Trauma Recovery Model and by employing an approach that is strengths based, and person centred.The Provider will work with individuals to achieve positive outcomes in line with their assessed needs and to meet the expectations of the Child or Young Person.Acknowledging that each provider must work within the parameters of an individual Child or Young Person’s care and support plan, this is an outcome focused service, where the delivery of outcomes important to each individual Child or Young Person in a rights-based approach, are monitored for quality.

Title: A  Development Agreement for the development and management of a supported living accommodation and day centre
Description: The Council is undertaking a competitive flexible procurement procedure to appoint a Supplier to enter into a Development Agreement with the Council.The Supplier (Development Partner) will design, apply and secure planning permission for, construct, deliver and manage a supported living accommodation and a learning disability day centre  at the former Garth Olwg Residential Care Home site, Main Road, Church Village, Pontypridd CF38 2DX.  It is anticipated that the development partner will secure relevant Welsh Government grant funding for the project. Dependent on the amount of funding secured the Council may be required to make a financial contribution as a top up.  A service level agreement will be established between the Local Authority and the chosen development partner once the facility is operational for the management of the relevant services including ongoing service charges and costs. The length of the service level agreement is to be determined but is anticipated to be around a 40 year period.   The service charges and costs may be negotiated as part of the tender procedure. Therefore the estimated cost provided for in this notice is based purely on an estimation of the void space over a 40 year period.  The competitive flexible procedure allows the Council to carry out the tender in multiple stages, although the Council reserves the right to award the contract based on initial tenders.

Title: New Bicester HWRC (Household Waste Recycling Centre) consultancy support

Currently, this area is served only by the HWRC at Ardley Fields, which is not owned by the Council and is subject to a lease expiring in September 2026.The proposed new HWRC in Bicester is intended to replace the Ardley Fields site upon its closure.Oxfordshire County Council is seeking to appoint a consultancy to act as Principal Designer, Technical Advisor, and Project Manager. The appointed Supplier will be responsible for the design, planning, procurement of the Principal Contractor, and overall delivery of the project.The Supplier is expected to provide a multi-disciplinary design service in accordance with the OCC Consultant Scope of Services – Traditional.Keywords:Consultancy, HWRC, Construction

Title: Groundworks for Modular Toilet Block
Description: The project involves the installation of a new modular public WC facility at Longforth Road toreplace the accident-damaged building demolished in 2024.The successful contractor will: Undertake the role of Principal Contractor under the CDM Regulations 2015. Establish, manage, and maintain safe site operations. Deliver the substructure works, including foundations, drainage, incoming services,and associated external works, in accordance with the design provided. Coordinate with the modular unit supplier (Danfo Limited) for delivery, siting, andinstallation. Manage subcontractors and programme sequencing to ensure safe and efficientcompletion. Oversee commissioning and final handover of the facility for public use.

Title: Invitation to tender for a National Public Awareness Campaign on Prostitution, Pornography, and Sexual Exploitation
Description: Ruhama is a National NGO providing support services to women impacted by prostitution and human trafficking for sexual exploitation. Ruhama provides wrap-around support for women, (the sex trade is a highly gendered phenomena) which supports them in dealing with the immediate impacts of trauma, through various support mechanisms. We work to identify positive goals for the future and through educational and personal development work towards independent living and mainstream employment opportunities. Services are offered based on each individual women’s needs using a trauma informed approach. Ruhama also advocates to influence policy that supports and protects women. Ruhama invites proposals from experienced campaign and research consultancies to devise and manage all aspects of a proposed national public awareness campaign on prostitution, pornography and sexual exploitation. This will comprise 2 phases: firstly, the development of comprehensive research tools to generate evidence-based insights which will inform and guide a future public awareness campaign, and secondly, the development of a campaign strategy and messaging content for this campaign. The successful consultant will at all phases of this project work in close collaboration with Ruhama both in devising the research approach and in the development of the strategy and messaging content. The ultimate objective of the project is to inform the public on issues around sex purchase, the legislative landscape in which it occurs and the supports available to individuals within the sex trade. It will ultimately seek to change behaviour around the consumption of pornography and the purchase of sex, and to move the dial on public tolerance for same.

Subject to suitability, the Authority is seeking to appoint up to 3 Contractors to each lot on this Framework.The overall framework will have an estimated total value of £3,600,000 (VAT inclusive)The Framework duration is for 4 years.Keywords:Antiskid Surfacing, Road Markings

Description: Chemonics Group UK Limited, implementing the Partnership Fund for a Resilient Ukraine - Phase 2 (PFRU-2) Project within the framework of international technical assistance, invites you to submit a Tender Proposal for the Major renovation of the premises of the neurology department of the cardiology building at 1 Sergiya Fainblata Street in Bilhorod-Dnistrovskyi, Odesa Region.PFRU-2 is a multi-donor programme managed by the UK's Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office (FCDO) in cooperation with the Government of Ukraine. Under this project, PFRU-2 seeks a qualified supplier for Major renovation of the premises of the neurology department of the cardiology building at 1 Sergiya Fainblata Street in Bilhorod-Dnistrovskyi, Odesa Region.Please note the following key tender details:Submission deadline: 12 December 2025, 15:00 (Kyiv time)Deadline for questions: 5 December 2025, 15:00 (Kyiv time)All correspondence regarding this tender must be in writing to pfruprocurement@chemonics.comAll offers must be submitted electronically to pfruprocurement@chemonics.comThe subject line of all emails must state the tender number: PFRU2-2025-209.The Project is tax-exempt under the Technical Assistance Framework; therefore, all prices must be quoted net of VAT.

Title: The Tees Bay Dunes Management / Improvement Plan
Description: The Tees Protected Site Strategy (PSS) is transforming how Teesside balances its industrial heritage with nature recovery, bringing together environmental organisations, major industries and local communities to protect the internationally important Teesmouth and Cleveland Coast designated sites. This collaborative initiative directly supports the regional ambitions to become the UK's clean energy powerhouse whilst ensuring the Tees estuary remains a thriving habitat for seals, migratory birds and other wildlife that depends on its mudflats and salt marshes. Sand dunes play a huge role in coastal protection, as well as host a diverse and high-quality invertebrate assemblage associated with sand dune habitats. The Tees Bay dunes condition status is unfavourable - declining, and the dunes network faces a multitude of pressures. Working at landscape-scale to develop a long-term (30-year) sustainable strategy for the dune system will provide evidence-based information to inform decision-making and direct actions for nature recovery. This project is seeking a provider to work collaboratively with landowners and land managers to develop and produce a 30-year Tees Bay Dunes Management Plan.

Title: Air Monitors Servicing and Maintenance Contract
Description: • Twice-annual servicing of the air quality monitoring station equipment and visual inspection of air conditioning equipment. • A call-out service for any responsive repairs required (to both the air quality monitoring equipment and the air conditioning units within the monitoring stations). • Replacement and calibration of gas cylinders. • Insurance policy/ies to cover all costs in relation to responsive repairs of the air quality monitoring equipment and air conditioning equipment.

Title: Asset Investment Management Planning (inc Cost Capture & Modelling & Cost Estimation)
Description: Anglian Water intends to procure and implement a modern, scalable, cloud-based Asset Investment Planning and Management (AIPM) system delivered as a SaaS solution. The system must enable optimised, risk-informed investment decisions across the asset base and support long-term planning (up to 50 years), cost-benefit optimisation, emergent risk management, cost capture and modelling, and cost estimation. It should integrate seamlessly with existing digital architecture, improve transparency, regulatory compliance, and deliver whole-life value from asset investments while remaining adaptable to emerging risks and business priorities. The anticipated contract term is 10 years from implementation, with an estimated value of £8,000,000.

Title: Dormant Assets Scheme Insolvency Solution
Description: Should the disorderly insolvency of a Scheme participant occur, RFL would need to provide a B2C solution that mirrors the value that, and process by which, ‘live’ customers can be compensated through the firm’s insolvency practitioner.RFL is seeking to outsource this B2C solution and have it on standby, ready to be activated within a reasonable timeframe that mirrors the insolvency practitioner’s reclaim service should it become apparent that a participant is facing a disorderly insolvency.Activation of the B2C solution would be directed by RFL, based on information received from the participant’s insolvency practitioner and/or the FCA that confirms a disorderly insolvency.RFL wishes to procure a business process outsourcing (BPO) service that can calculate, validate, and process customer reclaims using data obtained from the participant’s insolvency practitioner. The BPO must securely store the data, with appropriate access controls governing it.  The BPO service will need to be proportionate and appropriate to the insolvency event: it must be scalable (both up and down) and adapt to the insolvency practitioner, which will determine ways of working, processes, and timelines. RFL recognises these unique requirements will require a sophisticated and bespoke solution and is therefore anticipating that the supplier is likely to sub-contract elements. RFL must be assured that the overall solution is compliant with RFL policies and procedures, FCA and other regulations, that customers receive appropriate outcomes, and that appropriate service standards are achieved.To view this notice, please click here: https://www.delta-esourcing.com/delta/viewNotice.html?noticeId=994516375

Title: Rail Network Investment Framework
Description: The purpose of this project is to undertake an independent actuarial review of Network Rail's Industry Risk Fund (IRF) and Network Rail Risk Fee Fund (NRFF). Both funds are central mechanisms of the Rail Network Investment Framework (RNIF) and are designed to provide third-party promoters with protection against defined liabilities when delivering enhancement projects on the national rail network.

Title: Silk Road Steppe landscape Architect Procurement - RBGKEW1479
Description: Wakehurst’s identity as a botanic garden is rooted in the rigour of its horticulture, conservation, and scientific research. The proposed Silk Road Steppe Landscape builds on this foundation, reinforcing Wakehurst’s global reputation as a leading site for ecologically inspired horticulture.The Silk Road conjures a sense of mystery, adventure, and cultural exchange. Spanning over 800 km of ancient trade routes between Europe and Asia, it traverses mountains, expansive steppes, bustling cities, and arid deserts. This region is among the most floristically rich and diverse on Earth, yet faces increasing threats from habitat loss, conflict, and industrial agriculture.The Silk Road also tells a compelling story of humanity’s deep-rooted relationship with plants—our reliance on them for food, medicine, and materials. Many of today’s edible, medicinal, and timber species trace their origins to the movement and cultivation of plants along these historic routes.It is this rich cultural and ecological tapestry that has inspired the concept for Wakehurst’s new garden.  Estimated value is £1,700,000 including VAT.For more information about this opportunity, please visit the Delta eSourcing portal at: https://www.delta-esourcing.com/tenders/UK-UK-Richmond:-Buildings-of-particular-historical-or-architectural-interest./4T9P3F5DU8To respond to this opportunity, please click here: https://www.delta-esourcing.com/respond/4T9P3F5DU8

Title: Carbon Calculator for Tourism & Event Businesses

The ambition is for it to be freely available for businesses and event organisers that have started their Climate Action Plan, with the carbon calculator being made accessible to them via the business support hub and business support programme.Lot 1: VisitScotland is now seeking a ready-made tourism and events-specific carbon calculator that is independently verified, which will suit the needs of businesses across several different sectors and differing sizes. The ambition is for it to be freely available for businesses and event organisers that have started their Climate Action Plan, with the carbon calculator being made accessible to them via the business support hub and business support programme.

Title: CPU6938 Exported Electricity
Description: Nottingham City Council is seeking tenders from registered Electricity Suppliers in the UK to purchase the electricity export and the associated ROCs and REGO’s from a Steam Turbine Embedded Generator owned and operated by Nottingham City Council Tenders are invited by Nottingham City Council (NCC) who own and operate a steam turbine located within the City that provides power to a private wire network and exports excess electricity to the local distribution grid. The steam is provided from the waste and energy facility at Eastcroft and the steam turbine is located at the London Rd Heat Station within the City. The generator also produces Renewable Obligation Certificates (ROC’s) and Renewable Electricity Guarantees of Origin certificates (REGO Certificates).Keywords:Electricity

Title: Leasing and Managing Council-owned Family Temporary Accommodation - Premarket Engagement
Description: Service Overview: Supported Temporary Accommodation for FamiliesThe Council is seeking to engage with suitably qualified and experienced registered providers of social housing to deliver a portfolio of supported temporary accommodation units for families experiencing housing need. This provision will form part of the Council’s wider housing strategy to ensure safe, secure, and appropriate accommodation for vulnerable households, with a particular focus on family units requiring urgent placement.The proposed service model will incorporate both accommodation and support functions. Registered providers of social housing will be expected to deliver a supported housing offer, which includes tailored assistance to residents aimed at promoting tenancy sustainment, financial resilience, and pathways into settled accommodation. Support may include, but is not limited to, help with budgeting, accessing benefits, navigating housing options, and engaging with relevant statutory and voluntary services.In addition to support provision, the successful registered provider of social housing will be responsible for delivering comprehensive tenancy and housing management services across the portfolio. This will include:•Booking clients into appropriate accommodation units•Managing voids and ensuring timely turnaround of properties•Undertaking responsive and planned repairs and maintenance•Ensuring compliance with health and safety and housing standards•Acting as the primary point of contact for residents regarding tenancy mattersThe Council expects registered providers of social housing to operate with a high level of professionalism, responsiveness, and commitment to quality, ensuring that both the physical environment and the support offer contribute to positive outcomes for families in temporary accommodation.Please download, complete and submit the Soft Market Questionnaire linked to the ProContract PortalKeywords:Support Functions, Social Housing, Supported Housing, Management, Temporary Accommodation, Tenancy Sustainment

Title: Framework for Home Care Services in Herefordshire – Meet the Buyer / Market Engagement Event
Description: Herefordshire Council will be running a Market Engagement event for all businesses interested in delivering Home Care Services in Herefordshire. These services are commissioned for residents with assessed eligible needs, in order to enable them to remain safe and independent in their own homes for longer, reducing or delaying the need for more formal health and social care services. The engagement event will take place on Thursday 04 December 2025 at HARC (Herefordshire Archive and Record Centre), Fir Tree Lane, Rotherwas Industrial Estate, Hereford, Herefordshire, HR2 6LA.There are three sessions available throughout the day and providers are limited to 2 attendees per provider:Session 1: 10am – 11:30am (arrive from 9:30am)Session 2: 12:30pm – 2pm (arrive from 12pm)Session 3: 3pm – 4:30pm (arrive from 2:30pm)Each session will cover the following topics: information of where to find council opportunities, how to successfully bid for them and specific information about this project along with opportunities to ask questions and network.ALL SUPPLIERS WHO WISH TO ATTEND WOULD NEED to e-mail Jo Morris, Commissioning Officer, at [email protected] by Thursday 27 November 2025 and confirm:•Your organisation name •Name, position and e-mail address for your one / two attendees •The session you wish to attendPlease note, for health and safety purposes, we will be unable to admit any attendees who have not booked in advance of the event.Keywords:home care

Title: Metal Roofing Sheet Refurbishment Works
Description: The Council is seeking to appoint a supplier in relation to Metal Roofing sheet Refurbishment Works. The full scope as outlined in the Tender Information Pack attached.The City Council owns a range of Commercial and Corporate properties, including Lancaster Bus Station, White Lund Depot Workshops and Salt Ayre Leisure Centre.These properties all have metal roofing sheet which has been identified for refurbishment, along with other roof related works. By way of an overview, works include re-coating the metal roofing sheet, cut edge treatment, soft and fascia patch repair and treatment, gutter cleaning and lining.These properties are busy operational sites, mostly open to the public. The continuation of operations with minimal disruption will be essential for the success of these projects.

Title: Water Hygiene Maintenance Services
Description: Summary of Contract Scope for Water Hygiene ServicesThe contract shall contain a number of sites across London & Windsor.Applicants must be technically able to deliver against the contract scope as follows:a. Planned maintenance according to the water risk assessment written schemes across all sites.b. Reactive water hygiene remedials arising from water sampling results across all sites detailed above.c. Routine maintenance of plant equipment, including magnetic filters, Orca copper silver systems, water softeners, ENWA filtration units, and swimming pools.d. Improvement, corrections and adjustments to water systems, as recommended under the risk assessment.e. Additional plumbing works, as agreed.f. Additional water hygiene sampling and other services, as agreed.g. Receive, update, and close out work using the RHPS CAFM system.h. Performance of all maintenance services in accordance with regulatory requirements and recommendations (e.g. O&M manuals and manufacturer’s recommendations), as appropriate to each Royal Household Property.i.Maintain industry standards and best practice maintenance and operation throughout the Royal Household Estates.j.Undertake full safety checks on all relevant systems, plant and equipment to ensure full compliance with European and British Standards, Building and Fire Safety Regulations, other statutory and legislative minimum standards, the requirements of the RHPS, and any other relevant technical publications.k.Perform asset list validation and asset tagging of water system assets in the first 90 days of the contract via the RHPS CAFM system. This includes updating relevant schematics and drawings to reflect updates / changes.l.Record and publish findings in regular service reports, including identifying low-use outlets, vacant properties and out of bounds / construction areas that could pose increased risk to water hygiene.m.Maintain all systems appropriate to the operating parameters of the Royal Household Property and assets.n.Provide training tools and materials to RHPS personnel, including for flushing and other agreed activities.o.Endeavour to prolong system life and recommend to the RHPS any variations to system requirements, that would reflect improved value for money. The first report will be six (6) months post the commencement date of the contract.p.Identify to the RHPS team energy and water optimization and reduced utility consumption opportunities. The first report will be six (6) months post the commencement date of the contract.q.Identify potential system risks, and suggest innovative improvements or solutions.r.Propose improved control mechanisms and additional equipment to improve the systems.s.Identify opportunities to reduce energy consumption and carbon emissions.t.Maintain all work areas in a clean, tidy and safe condition free from oil, grease, dust, debris, foreign objects, inappropriate storage and rubbish which will include keeping all work areas in an orderly state.u.Regular reporting to the RHPS, where the contract will be reviewed against Key Performance Indicators (KPIs).To view this notice, please click here: https://www.delta-esourcing.com/delta/viewNotice.html?noticeId=991517905

Title: Construction of Red Smiddy to Erskine Active Travel Route Phases 4, 5 and 6
Description: Renfrewshire Council wishes to appoint a single Contractor to undertake two contracts: 1. Phases 4 and 5 will be for the construction of 1.4km of shared footway and cycleway from the end of the existing shared footway/cycleway on Greenock Road, round Red Smiddy Roundabout, north onto Southbar Road to Southholm Roundabout. There is an existing footway at Red Smiddy Roundabout which is widened, and new construction on Southbar Road. In places the existing carriageway is widened. 2. Phase 6 will be for the construction of 0.616km of shared footway and cycleway from Southholm Roundabout to the overbridge on the A726 on the northbound verge. This will include the relocation of street lighting columns, road signs and installation of new drainage. The works will involve the construction of a ramp to create a connection to the existing footway overbridge over the A726. The Council will award both contracts for this project to one Contractor.Lot 1: Renfrewshire Council wishes to appoint a single Contractor to undertake two contracts: 1. Phases 4 and 5 will be for the construction of 1.4km of shared footway and cycleway from the end of the existing shared footway/cycleway on Greenock Road, round Red Smiddy Roundabout, north onto Southbar Road to Southholm Roundabout. There is an existing footway at Red Smiddy Roundabout which is widened, and new construction on Southbar Road. In places the existing carriageway is widened. 2. Phase 6 will be for the construction of 0.616km of shared footway and cycleway from Southholm Roundabout to the overbridge on the A726 on the northbound verge. This will include the relocation of street lighting columns, road signs and installation of new drainage. The works will involve the construction of a ramp to create a connection to the existing footway overbridge over the A726. The Council will award both contracts for this project to one Contractor.

Team Leadership 6N10948. Training, Delivery and Evaluation 6N3326

Title: Flexible Procurement Agreement for the Children and Young People's Framework
Description: The funding for children and young people's programmes intends to build an inclusive economy, where all children and young people have equal opportunities to realise their potential and be part of the region's future success.To achieve this, the former North of Tyne Combined Authority launched a Children and Young People's Flexible Procurement Framework for delivery in the North of Tyne area and invited a wide range of organisations and providers including public and private sector, independent training organisations, Voluntary and Community Sector Organisations (VCSE) organisations and other stakeholders, to tender for a place on the Framework. Following the transition of North of Tyne Combined Authority to the North East Combined Authority, encompassing four additional local authority areas, the North East CA is now reopening this framework to enable procurement of activity across the full North East CA. The Flexible Procurement Framework will initially be utilised to procure providers for North East CA investment fund allocation for excellence in education and child poverty reduction programmes.Lot 1: Child Poverty ReductionThe North East Child Poverty Action plan is an ambitious, evidence-informed plan which setsout our determination to use the collective levers andresources we have available here in the North East toprevent and reduce child poverty. This represents asignificant investment, from the very earliest stages, inour single most important asset as a region: our people. We know that the North East can be the bestplace in the world to grow up, live and raise afamily - but this isn't the case for far too manypeople in our region. Our vision is for the North East to be a place where every baby, child and young person issupported to thrive and achieve their potential- regardless of their background, or wherethey live. The child poverty reduction programme speaks to the three strategic priorities within the regional action plan, which has been developed following extensive engagement with a broad range of cross-sector organisations, parents, carers, and young people across the region,:Supporting children and families here and now- including by doing what we can together to help families maximise their incomesBreaking down the barriers to opportunity that poverty can bring,  including by collectively investing more in giving babies, children and young people the best start in lifeTackling longer-term, structural challenges - including those which will help to make work pay, and create the infrastructure of opportunity for more familiesLot 2: Education ImprovementNorth East CA's Excellence in Education forms part of our Home of Real Opportunity portfolio and exemplifies a commitment to thinking creatively and progressively about the widest implications of an inclusive economy. We are dedicated to giving everyone the opportunity to thrive - to achieve and access good jobs, working with businesses, civil society, and our residents to achieve this.Our current programme of work has 3 objectives:InclusionRealising PotentialTeacher Wellbeing and Development

Title: Provision of Paediatric Oximetry and TOSCA Home Testing for Children's Health Ireland (CHI)
